zS4dgSi662EmGqCLMhMYFg.review_text: Amazing cocktail service! This restaurant has a great atmosphere. I sat at the bar and had a few drinks with friends. After exploring the menu, which an amazing bartender Chad helped us navigate, we all split a delicious appetizer from the bar menu. Great for a date night or hanging with the homies. I will surely be back.

mE-hdFF4RgCxspZU72GAsw.review_text: Been years since I've been to this old-school spot and was truly impressed with the overhaul. The fused enhancement--keeping the classic, faded North Beach charm with the addition of an excellent mixology program and hip cooking--really worked well. Definitely shell out for one of the menu cocktails, I loved the Suffering Bastard (always try a bastard drink) as well as the the Polo Cup. The Oaxacan Firing Squad will be perfect for anyone enjoying the Mezcal craze. Their Rosita differs greatly from my understanding of the recipe, so I'll have to try this one next time. On the food front, best thing is to share all your dishes for the optimal experience. Props for the pressed pig ears which we reluctantly tried. They tasted a bit like bacon sashimi, if such a thing exists, and we were pleasantly surprised. Make sure to add a tad of salt to the pieces lying under the top piece as a means to bring out the best flavor. The moscardini, aka octopus is tender, grilled, and I'm sure you will love it if you are a mollusk fan, like me. For mains, they were out of the cod, major bummer, so we got and loved the grilled polenta. The pork sausage is worth a go as well, very tender and different from any other. We were so full but tried the cannoli for dessert. Like everything, it was great. Can't wait to return. PS: Outstanding A+ service.

c8FOqDRhtL7q_YsQio6bog.review_text: Tosca - it's so good to have you back.  This used to be one of my favorite North Beach watering holes back in the day. It's one of SF's classic bars. Many a celebrity used to frequent the place (and their infamous "private back room"), including: Sean Penn, Francis Ford Coppola, and famous rock stars. But over the years, Tosca started to experience some noticeable wear and tear in both upkeep and service. Finally, it was at risk of shutting down... until the team behind New York's Spotted Pig swooped in to the rescue. After a few months of revamping the interior, updating their bar program, and adding a kitchen, Tosca's doors are open again. And the best way I can describe the change - it's a like an old friend who's studied abroad over a year, and now he's back and a changed person. It's still the same old friend that you know and love, but just more sophisticated and mature (and quite frankly, the better for it).  My co-workers and I came in here the other night for some holiday cocktails and grub. After wading through the crowded, narrow bar area, we finally made it to their dining area. Fortunately for us, they were able to seat us right away. Looking around the room, everything looked somewhat familiar (the wooden bar, the large Rat Pack-style booths) but more spruced up than i remember. Obviously, the most notable change to Tosca is the kitchen and the smell of food. Our thirsty/hungry gang ordered some festive adult beverages and anti-pasti (pickled peppers, grilled octopus, roasted Romaine with pine nuts, charcutterie, fresh focaccia bread). I wound up sipping on a classic Negroni on the rocks (or one giant rock, I should say). This is an old-school cocktail and very easy to screw up if you over-pour one the Campari or Sweet Vermouth. My Negroni was perfectly balanced. One of the best ones I've ever had. I then indulged in their Point Reyes Blue salad (Heirloom Radicchios, Croutons, Dutch Shallots, blue cheese dressing). It was kind of like a more sophisticated take on a Wedge salad. I loved it. In fact, I pretty much licked my plate clean.  One warning - this place is LOUD. If you're looking for an intimate night out, this isn't the place to go. You'll be shouting at each other the whole night long.  All in all, we had a most enjoyable time at the new Tosca, I'm delighted to see it surviving and thriving in its new incarnation.

f4TmkSqamLyujpBSDksGcQ.review_text: The wait was forever to get in. Doesn't take reservations. Service isn't very attentive nor helpful on ordering or answering questions. meal was burnt.

hpzBhu442zZMGaARnucwbQ.review_text: We lost a good bar and got an obnoxiously crowded overpriced restaurant.This used to be a nice quiet place to get a drink when everything else in the area was packed. Now the wait for a table is at least an hour even early on a Tuesday night.

81f0X1axCd9gIF9LCEJz5g.review_text: I had high expectations because of The Spotted Pig so I was secretly hoping it was going to be as good.  While I did see the reviews here, I wanted to give the restaurant a chance.  It was a bit of a disappointment.  Like others have said on here, the food is salty.  Some of the dishes were overly salty that I drank so much water during dinner and drank more water when I got home.  That said the meatballs, gemelli and linguine were great (but could have a bit less salt).  For main I had the braised oxtail and I found it mediocre. The meat was a bit gummy probably from too much fat and oils - needed more braising time.    I got the gelati thinking it would be a palate cleanser from the too salty food but even that had salt!  I couldn't believe it - they sprinkled salt on top!!  For the wine lovers, note that they store their wines on a wall out in the open with accent lighting behind them.  I hope they go through the bottles quickly.  The exposure to heat and temperature fluctuation is not good.   On the plus side, they finally got their act together and you can now book a table via OpenTable instead of standing in line.  There aren't many tables so highly recommend making a reservation.  With so many other wonderful restaurants in SF, I don't think I'll come back.

Yi5JKaD1VY4Edeww92PZWA.review_text: The new Tosca is amazing, and by far the best food/drink spot in North Beach. We went on a Tuesday night and it was really busy. The wait for a dinner table was around an hour, so we put our name down and took a seat at the bar. The staff was very friendly and made some delicious cocktails. My favorite drink is the Polo Cup (with gin), followed closely by the Cap Haitian Apple Toddy and the Bennet. While at the bar we ordered the marinated olives, the fennel salad, and the moscardini (octopus salad). The octopus was incredible, as was the fennel. Everything was done to perfection and tasted like food you would get in Italy. Once we were sat at a table, we ordered the two specials, a meatball dish and a crab salad. The crab was super fresh and the dressing was a crab-ceasar dressing. The meatballs were made of three types of meat and were extremely tasty. For the entree we split the bucatini and I was blown away by how good it was. I usually don't order pasta at restaurants, but this pasta was perfectly al dente with a rich tomato sauce.   It was an overall perfect meal. The decor is warm and inviting; a mixture of the new and the old. I love this place and I can't wait to go back.

IJUoKDLuxj8_2yXuYdzEBA.review_text: Ok. I don't review but I eat out all the time. I think this is my new thing . I have been told yelp is very fickle so I hope this makes it. Tosca has kept it charms...juke box is still the same (thank you). Drinks good . Here is where I have my problem...order your whole order at once . I get pacing but give me a break. Orders will only be taken once you have come to a consensus?? Orders came and it was for the table next to us. Nice pacing. Total salt lick once the food arrived.

4Y81J2Tdq5XAnkeYmCZ2ow.review_text: I half expected a celebrity spotting at the newly face-lifted Tosca, with it's Rat Pack grandeur still peeking through the new polish. My friend tells a story of the time he watched a fancy car pull up right in front of Tosca, moved the orange parking cones out of the way, and claimed the restricted zone as his parking spot. The rockstar parking suddenly made sense when Huey Lewis stepped out and waltzed into Tosca.   Fast forward to 2013...only rowdy, cocktail-sloshing businessmen lined the bar on this chilly December night. The atmosphere is very North Beach: tightly-packed, with that European brand of unusual weekday vivacity. The narrow front half of the space is all bar, the back half is a small dining room with leather booths and a few casual dining tables. As we squeezed our way to the hostess stand, we passed the charcuterie station where hunks of cured meat were being sliced paper thin. Little bowls of olives, octopus, peppers, and fresh foccacia beckoned a bar snack. I never knew the old Tosca, but I was feeling optimistic about the new one.  We were able to get a table for 6 with no reservation on a Wednesday night. From there, we sampled the drink & antipasti menu. The wines by the glass are limited and pricey - most reds are $12-13, so you might as well try a cocktail. Their signature is the "House Cappucino" (Armagnac, Bourbon, Chocolate Ganache, Organic Milk). Tempting, but you've got to be in the right mood.   The antipasti menu is great for bar snacking with things like: Giardiniera (pickled peppers), Moscardini (grilled octopus), and Roasted Treviso (roasted romaine with pine-nuts). From the dining room, you can see the open kitchen where the main courses come out: fancy incarnations of pasta & polenta, Italian meat dishes, and classic desserts. Starters are $9-16, Secondi entrees $15-17, and Mains $29-42. Basically, a drink and a snack will run you about $25.   Service was fine -- not overly friendly, as you might (unfortunately) expect in a posh new spot. The food was creative & comforting, and the ambiance is sleek & lively. Overall, Tosca has retained the simplicity of an Italian taverna with the panache of a modern SF dining destination. If you're curious, it's worth a taste!

reQcVFgEEFdFmFrFycMHXw.review_text: I had been before for the drinks (fantastic cocktails. And the only place I know of in sf that has all 5 ages of pappy van winkle). Last night I went for dinner and everything was terrific. Sat our group of 5 within 15 minutes. Great food and service. Highly recommended.

5YlCQ3EfFBb9NWZbUPScDA.review_text: This place really deserves one star, but the bartender was so good, they get two stars.    We sat down to eat at the bar since the dining area was waiting for reservation parties to arrive.  After ordering a drink each and some dinner,  I was asked for my credit card.  Really?  You claim to be an upscale place?  WTF?  I felt like I had just ordered at In N Out and pay before I put a morsel of food in my mouth.  I was somewhat steaming, so I spoke to the manager and he politely said it was the restaurant's policy.  I should have paid for the drinks right then and there and left!  The food arrived (chicken for two) and it was good, but a bit salty as others have claimed.  The meatball appetizer was small (three little meatballs), but flavorful.  I was so irked over the pay before you eat, I couldn't really dig this place.  And..when I got back to L.A., I stopped at Sprout's and picked up a rotisserie chicken which was actually better than the $42 chicken from Tosca.  Oh well, will not return to Tosca.  Far too many great places in SF to waste another meal at Tosca.

sU_VYz_7W5zVGLbIn-hfGA.review_text: We had a phenomenal  night at Tosca!  Sat at the bar and shared the bar panini, which was delicious.  Chad was  awesome -- Each drink we had was perfection!

a-G-LUBYtZkMMnntRn26AA.review_text: Not sure if this new and improved version of Tosca is a diner/bar or bar/restaurant...  I arrived at 7:15  PM on Saturday, April 5, to join friends at the bar before having dinner. We were seated at a booth shortly afterwards.  The waiter tried unsuccessfully to announce the specials to us, twice,  but the noise plus the loud music playing in the background made it impossible to hear the specials. Instead, we decided to focus on the menu, and after a brief review of the limited menu choices and the above average prices, by mutual agreement, we left and went elsewhere in North Beach.  BTW: At the bar we noted that one of the bartenders was clearly under the influence, and openly knocked back a shot glass of something other than H20. Not sure if drinking on the job is tolerated, but there was no attempt to be discrete about it.  Otherwise, the new Tosca looks a lot better than the original but is clearly designed to attract the under-30 demographic.

WzpS9g-sbaXfEqoaYLgPfw.review_text: SUCH. A. LONG. WAIT.  I'm annoyed just thinking about the wait itself. The food itself is good - which is why I felt like yelling at them "GET YOUR ACT TOGETHER - THIS COULD BE AMAZING". After having waited for 1hr40mins (not my choice, a friend really really wanted to try this place) we were told that a table was being set, but we'd have to wait another 10 minutes because they were "trying to pace the kitchen". Really? At least let us sit down and liquor up!  They have an item on the menu (chicken for 2) which says "please allow us 1 hour to prepare". We thought OK (even though we've already been waiting for an hour and 40 minutes), we'll order lots of appetizers and pastas, etc. and at the end, the chicken will come out and will be amazing. 2 hours after we had been seated - there was no sign of any chicken. We had to check in again to make sure it was coming. When it did come out - it was truly divine. So moist. So flavorful.   Overall - I would never ever return again. Because the wait makes it such a negative experience (as evidenced by the really low star average on yelp). But it's unfortunate - because the food is tasty!

WcSUyRH_EzUfqKua1m93DA.review_text: I fell in love with this place the moment I walked in. The fact that is so classy and old school make you happy. Sometimes you forget about these things when you visit all these hip new restaurants in SF.  Anyways, the food, drinks and service were impeccable. Started with the Giardiniera (Pickled Veg) and the Point Reyes Blue Salad (so rich a delicious). Great starter combo I might ad. For the meal, I had the Bucatini (pasta cooked perfectly, great flavors), the meatballs (had to order with pasta - delicious) and the roasted cauliflower (YOU HAVE TO ORDER, DON'T LEAVE WITHOUT IT!) Last but not least you have to order the tiramisu. The orange zest completes it.   During dinner I left the wine choices up to the server, which was a great idea. He knew a great deal of information and selected wines that went perfectly with each dish.   I left satisfied, fat and full. I'll be back without a doubt. This time Sean Penn better be there!

IDy0O2yiKuIPTrTuxwi6Xg.review_text: One of my favorite places to visit while in town. But this time was very disappointed. Waited 25 minutes to be acknowledged. Came in for their famous House Cap. About 30 minutes later was brought just a regular coffee.  Had to wait an additional 20 minutes after finding someone who would help us get it right. Such a let down. Had to track down he server to pay our bill. Probably won't be back unfortunately.

Z5JJ1e95WSo8Bsw_zvl8HQ.review_text: Ok the PR Machine that is the hallmark signature of new ownership has worn off and the reality is that Bono is not serving me drinks, Sean Penn is not bussing tables and Robin Williams is nowhere to be seen. All that is left is the reality that this washed out place is still washed out, now just expensive and run by a bunch a NYC dickheads. Skip it and go to Delfina for some quality SF Italian!

eVy48PkO4CPqYwV5JMDZgQ.review_text: Had dinner on a Sunday in July.  The roast chicken was not on the menu.  Was very disappointed. All other items ordered tasted great.  $50 corkage for 2 bottles of wine we brought (one in our party is in the industry) and the server never poured a drop after the first pour.  I am guessing the chicken dish was not on the menu due to the Sunday family style supper being served that evening.  That was not suggested to our party when the server was going over the menu and taking our order.  Cool space, good food.  I would return on a night the chicken was back on the menu.

_q6XWUZYnoaqc9kYClxg_w.review_text: Tosca, was amazing. The food was A.Maze.Ing. The drinks were delicious. Love the renovations. It is a must spot in San Fran.

L4EiRoOH6cxPjiCUXxOcHQ.review_text: Thanks for agreeing with me Anna Roth at Eater.com. (do our reviews sound similar?) sfweekly.com/2013-11-20/…

w0ge5Edx6eouuNQuyOvuuA.review_text: The drinks and food here is some of the best you will ever have.   This place knows how to treat it's customers.  Exceptional customer service and exceptional food.  What more is there?  Quality through and through.

hLC4Iu-hjFiZMx4c7Bqrfg.review_text: I really wanted to like this place. After watching season 2 of Mind of a Chef on Netflix, we were so excited to try Tosca since it was featured on the show. I knew immediately we would order the meatballs made with guanciale, and the fried pig tails. We also had the turnips, the fried potatoes, the minestrone, the oxtail terrine, and the bucatini pasta. In the end, I could summarize my entire meal here in three words... TOO MUCH SALT. There was a consensus at our table and maybe even the one next to us. The flavors were there, and it breaks my heart because there was so much potential. Unfortunately, the salt rendered the food nearly inedible. Our table went through at least 5 or 6 pitchers of water to wash everything down. We most likely would not return. I gave 2 stars because the ambiance was decent, and the food was prepared well were it not for the salt. I also enjoyed the Tiramisu, if only because it was the one item that gave us reprieve from the salinity of the other dishes.

RwcoySTqRsFXN6wUDUmkEA.review_text: After hearing that Tosca made Bon Appétit's top 50, we immediately booked a reservation. Having been to the excellent Spotted Pig and John Dory in NYC, we expected greatness. Too bad Tosca fell so short of our expectations. The restaurant's decor is charming and comfortable. They did a great job of maintaining it's original vintage feel without resorting to clichéd reclaimed wood and filament bulbs. The service was slow and amateurish. The waiter presented the wine to my husband to taste even though I had been the one to order it. There were a couple of interesting tuna appetizers on the menu. The egg tonnato was very good, the egg making a natural pairing with tonnato sauce. It was a great alternative to the traditional veal recipe.  The tuna conserva with radishes on the other hand lacked brightness that should have counterbalanced the heavy oiliness of the tuna and the creaminess of the crème fraîche. The crispy pig tails, while cooked perfectly and full of flavor, were over-salted as were the crispy potatoes many of which were fried to death. The turnips were so very average. There weren't many enticing secondi choices. We settled on the hangar steak because we wanted a meat dish and didn't want to wait one hour for the chicken. Had we known the service would be so slow we might have ordered it. The hangar steak was tasty if uninventive. Not all the dishes were uninspired. The bucatini with guanciale and chile was undeniably the star dish of the evening. We should have foregone all the other dishes and just ordered 6 of those instead.

617f0bJTMgwuukhbRpHfAw.review_text: We walked into this place totally by accident. We live in nyc and are here on vacation. It looked pretty from outside so we decided to give it a try. WHAT A PLEASANT SURPRISE!!! It was totally Amazing. Try the meatballs I just ate an entire plate and can eat like 10 more. Even the water was perfect. Jordan our server was extremely kind and knowledgeable. DO NOT MISS THIS PLACE.

qdyC4LWk_TvoSgpM-P1M0g.review_text: I gave this place 6 or 7 tries...Awful experience.. This is a place you really feel unwelcome. The service sucks (the host is constantly pissed off and the same goes for the bartenders ). The food is so salty that you might need to check your blood pressure afterwards..I wish it was like Spotted Pig or  Breslin...

pmV8yMwGZzva2uCFwV-8sw.review_text: Wonderful date spot, nice ambiance with dim lighting, delicious small plates to share and the cappuccino---delightful.

-MyLPrB9K4d4XWRLE9KlMw.review_text: Had an early dinner here with friends before seeing a show.  I love the atmosphere here - the booths tucked into the walls, the lighting, decor, etc.  I like looking into the open kitchen & watching dishes get plated up before being sent out.  This was probably my favorite dinner during a recent trip to San Francisco.  The caesar salad was very good - the waiter said he loved the presentation of it & felt it wasn't your typical caeser.  It had a nice hit of heat to it.  It was a bit filling & I might have considered splitting it with a friend after I ate the whole thing & was close to full.  The next dish was the lumaconi with prosciutto & lemon breadcrumbs.  Um, OMG that was delicious!  I don't usually love to order anything with cream sauce b/c it's just too heavy for me....but this was a very light cream sauce & not excessive.  I just wish I had not eaten so much of my salad b/c I just couldn't finish my pasta.  The cocktails were also outstanding - I had the whiskey smash & enjoyed it. Loved the music playing on the jukebox.  My only knocks on the place are (1) the service - I thought it was just ok.  The waiter was not really very attentive, empty plates sat in need of clearing, another cocktail was not offered.  Yet I saw a lot of waiters just kind of hanging around in the corners of the restaurant.  (2) The bathroom - I get that this place is a former dive bar that hosted celebrities & has a long history - but today I'm at a nice restaurant & while your bathroom might be considered kitschy, it's old & a bit on the gross side.

ds_k6_mJ3Oi7BiSN4iQU-Q.review_text: Horrible service. Clueless hostess, absent waitress. However only reason in business is good food.  This year, we've been to SF several times and to NYC, Chicago, Philadelphia, New Orleans, Denver, LA, Phoenix, and Portland. Michelin-starred restaurants and hole-in-the-walls.  On this trip to SF, we ate at Tadich, La Folie, Akiko's,     Quince, and Mission Chinese.  Mission Chinese was awesome, even with service by one waiter at lunch for the entire dining room.  Tosca was the absolute worst for service.  No food is worth that experience at this kind of restaurant.

Z33ENXec3_VJRlymaDmQIw.review_text: Given that most places in SF roll up the sidewalk before 10pm, it is really nice to have a restaurant where you can swing by at 1030 and have a high quality meal in a vibrant but relaxed atmosphere.  Top notch service and food (pasta w mussels), with interesting cocktails.

wb3Tip9jwYT-1f73cvSyIQ.review_text: Was seated as soon as we walked in the door! The dining room is small and allows for personal service.  The food was delicious.  Would definitely recommend Tosca for any special event.

NGDgP4nAoAFbCNzwtlo1IA.review_text: The mussels were fishy and rubbery, had to turn it in, got the pesto pasta it was awful too.

gOEp68WaNgv1FqWT6TAXtg.review_text: I'm obsessed with this place. Remains my very favorite restaurant in SF. I used to love THE SPOTTED PIG in nyc and this place brings the hustle of a nyc kitchen to an otherwise gastronomically impoverished neighborhood. The focaccia is crispy -- so good! And the salumi platter is great. Don't miss the Cacio e Pepe, really well executed. Great cocktails too!

5-ngN0yVVNno60X5t_QOPw.review_text: They somehow kept the charm but managed to strip the soul of this place. Maybe it's the clientele.  Maybe it's because they got rid of the old timers who used to run the bar.  Maybe it's because the tank of a coffee machine sits dark in the corner now (most likely because they got rid of the people who had mastered that piece of machinery). Maybe it's because I paid $30 for two drinks when I FINALLY got attention from the bartender. There used to be something otherworldly about this place. Like stepping back in time. Now it just feels like every other overpriced yuppie bar in San Francisco. What a shame.

-g3XIcCb2b-BD0QBCcq2Sw.review_text: This review is only for the drinks, and let me tell you, these cocktails are AMAZING. I started off with a Diamond Spritz Fizz, and it was DELISH. Especially when it was a warm, lazy Friday and nothing caps off a rough work week like an amazing cocktail. I was about to order another one when I saw that my co-workers had moved onto the Polo Cup, which came garnished with a beautifully sliced cucumber. Other drinks that were ordered were Oaxacan Firing Squad (warning for males, this drink has manly ingredients, but is served up as bright pink), the Trouble in Paradise, and a few people tried their hand at the Dealer's Choice.  Overall, I thought the drinks here were truly outstanding, and would definitely come back here.

Ow_oHwqaBBRuUAiNrL8rRw.review_text: Went back to the new reopened Tosca's . Same look, they did clean the Pictures on the wall and they actually have a menu.  Full bar, however when we ordered a Cap Cod, bartender didn't know what it was , once told they didn't have cranberry juice? Didn't eat there. The menu was not my cup of tea. Chicken Liver,Pork Sausage, prosciutto, Grilled Lamb. Average range of entree $13.00. I had $13.00 glass of Red Wine, and went on my way.  The look of the food , looked good and probably was, so I can't really judge it, since i didn't taste it.  So if going for nostalgia, it's still there, but the crowd has changed with the prices. Oh yes and if wanting to eat, over an hour wait or you can eat at the bar, which is not very comfy and a tight squeeze.

Ve0LUwcrzxL7w0RYgY4Aaw.review_text: Cute little spot for a date or drinks/dinner with friends. Tonight I rolled through with 6 friends and though it's a Sunday night it was pretty packed around 9pm. Fortunately we were able to nab a recently vacated booth and enjoy a round of drinks.  The music ranged from Tom Petty and Bob Dylan to some current top 40. Definitely a great hangout for someone in their mid 20s-30s. Was too full from dinner elsewhere to try the food but many items jumped out at me.   At the top of the cocktail menu they feature a a signature drink called a Tosca Cappuccino that's definitely worth trying! I was tempted to try other drinks as well because the menu had a lot of interesting options, but going on the advice of a friend on a chilly winter night I couldn't resist tasting this 'adult hot chocolate.' Made with Marie Duffau Bas Armagnac, Buffalo Trace Bourbon, Dandelion Chocolate Ganache, and Milk, it's obvious why this is the house specialty cocktail. In fact, I'd come back just for that!  The lights are a little dim, the fixtures are clean but dated in a cool way, and hanging out there I definitely felt like I was out and about in a unique to SF spot. Just what I need when I'm visiting from out of town!

E5vMbJUjOxjr4AZ8y66trw.review_text: Tosca should have just closed, at least there would have been great memories and a reputation intact.  This new incarnation is just a steaming pile of douchery.  there is a certain type of person currently proliferating in the city who's hallmark characteristic is the desire to be fleeced like a lemming of their extravagant wages.  they will flock here and they will not leave disappointed.  small overpriced portions of mediocre fare coupled with lackadaisical service.  no thanks.

Sebeg4n6GwfjmlQO_qGADA.review_text: First restaurant review on yelp, because I am still processing how awesome our dinner last night was.   Every dish was mindblowing, from the meatballs to the chicken to the potatoes (yes, mindblowing potatoes, believe me). I've eaten at 20+ of Eater SF's top 38 in the last year and Tosca is the best dinner I've had in SF, in terms of food and service, without question.   Our first dishes were a little bit slow coming out (though we had wine on the table and none of us had noticed), so the staff went way above and beyond, bringing us multiple free appies AND a free extra bottle of the wine we were drinking. I wouldn't expect this again, but they really impressed us with how attentive they were.  Go, you won't be disappointed.

rLWW2l6oXyHrzv3TrbuBHg.review_text: I have been visiting Tosca since the 90s! I drank tequila with our former mayor Willie Brown there. It is under new mgmt but it has not evolved. I am not an expert/foodie but I know good food. This is NOT it! Salt, salt and more salt. Let me break it down for you. If you want pasta, go to Tomassos. If you want a Pimms cup, go to Romolo. If you want to settle for mediocrity, go to the new Tosca. Just sayin

aD-rsDe2S0e7jTkYD6ULaQ.review_text: Solid late night eats at an old school SF spot. 4.25 stars  Food: 4.5, Service: 3.5, Atmosphere 4 Cost to worth it rating: 3.5 (pastas ~$17, sides ~$8) Return worthiness: yes Eve award: best sit down SF late night meal  Highlights: - Special hot cocoa (aka house cappuccino: bourbon, chocolate ganache, etc how can you go wrong especially on a rainy night???  - Italian wedding soup: delicious, light, and topped with lots of Parmesan - Pastas: forget if we got the gemelli or bucatini but pasta was fresh and delicious - Crispy potatoes: tasty salty crunchy filling side - Late night meal: had a reservation at 12:30am on a Saturday night which was awesome  Lowlights:  - Waiter misheard us order a dish and fought us on it. Manager came over and was cool about it  Had a fun 2nd dinner and would return for more eats and that coffee.

iCr1Js7S3QIrNirF0_R1Aw.review_text: Took the family for dinner last night.  Good service, booth was a little small but was fine for us.  The food was excellent.  Adults loved the pig tails, kids not so much (too fatty).  Oxtail terrine was a hit and we LOVED the meatballs and foccacia.  Pastas were great and we really enjoyed the tiramisu and strawberry balsamic gelati.  Would definitely go back with friends, co-workers and or family.  Nice eclectic mix of patrons.

zCGGWSR7-klRlPPeZ9BT1A.review_text: 3 of us got there around 6pm (empty) on Wenesday 10/30/13 had a bottle of 2009 Antonotti 'PRAMARTEL', Bramaterra..$42, well made with that unmistakable "tarry"Italian underpinning,1 Manhattan ,1 "Bennet",$12 ea, a focaccia great $4, pig tails $9, 4 small crispy unctuous chunks, fried fresh artichoke hearts $9; 3 small meatballs $12!!! and not worth it, too rich, not seasoned assertively enough for me (bet they die) 5 or 6 chicken liver spiedini $7..arguably the best thing we tasted as well as the most reasonable  yum! The $42 giant roasted 1/2 chicken with the foot that i chomped up(3 1/2 lb.) on levain schmeared with ricotta and delicious chicken juices very tasty and moist. broccoli  $9!!! ok, potatoes$7 crispy yummy, and cauliflower $8!!! mushy feh..about $190 without tip. we thought they had comped our wine because one of our party knew & had talked to a staff person before we ate. mistake!! after we paid our bill the waiter guy. apologizing profusely, brought us a bill for the wine..oh well     go there for the chicken livers and the chicken and it's kinda worth it BOYCOTT THE MEATBALLS RIDICULOUS!  started off fairly quiet but by the time we left it was packed & very noisy. hard to hear across the table.  service so so

AJOCN_19rxCBXSVq_EnsHQ.review_text: Completely overrated - and a real shame it made Bon Apps list when there are actual amazing and worthy restaurants on the list (e.g., Estela in NYC).   The bar line is insane - and the service is sub-par. It's also so narrow that you should expect to get elbowed every 5 seconds, especially if you're a girl wearing a purse.

NHKJowBM-8mY2Iegfc87pQ.review_text: Time: 9:23pm/54°F cloudy  Purpose: After watching the CNY's parade walking Kearney street about to head back to car in local garage. Saw Tosca pretty hip and busy thinking why not.  Ambiance: From the outside looks modern after complete make over the bar area was fill. People smiling picking up food taking a sip here and there. Noise level was pretty darn close to not hearing each other may need hand gestures. Front to back looks good enough for anyone who walks in without RSVP.   Staff: This is were I had a problem with the bouncer guy. I stood there looking in trying to get pass him while he was flirting with the ladies. I know all too well with situations like this were you want to impress and hope you can get in their pants after. The guy was light skin black shave head with a suit and tie, walks and act like he owns the place. Shit being a local and have roots in little Italy as well as Chinatown I know most of the owners that operates in the area. He was piss that I try to walk past him without acknowledging him. For what? Your attention was turn towards to three ladies hehe haha there and here I didn't want to bother you. Don't try to talk to me in front of the ladies for showing off or might be an (ADD) aka attention deficit disorder.  Cleanliness: It's clean all around step in there for about 30 seconds til he pulls me back out.  Eats/Drinks: Didn't get a chance to eat or drink due to bouncer who wants to show who's boss.  Punch Line: Hip,vibrant,for the 35+ crowd,clean concept,nicely remodel,a little dim,hard to park after 6pm,located on a busy streets,lots of foot traffic during weekends,Hustler Club next door,lusty ladies gone,great picture of Transamerica building.  Final Thoughts: You see what happens when your role as a bouncer does to a person. It fucks up their mentality so they want to really show that they're are better than a door person. I don't see it that way, it's like security guards with badges trying to act like police. Remember now you maybe somebody there many look up to. When you finish your shift and clock out you're a regular average joe, don't think highly about yourself.

uBgxqn5PTyfyApOQyjyUtw.review_text: The mussels. Get the mussels. We refused to let the broth be taken away and ordered some focaccia to soak it all up. Oh. And the trouble in paradise...because who isn't a fan of that?

mhwcWLDpNXnKe568lQR9oA.review_text: Can you say rip off... $14.00 for an Irish Coffee and then the bartender asks if you would like to by a wine while you wait.  No more White Nuns which is the drink that Made Tosca famous, something about Kahlua being politically incorrect.  Please bring back the old Tosca!  Avoid!

ckO3UlBjpUtw_R62Hf89pw.review_text: Everything at Tosca is fantastic - food, drinks, decor.  We've been 3 times since it reopened, both for dinner and for drinks/snacks and the food is delicious and the cocktails are amazing.  We ordered the mazzafegati not even really knowing what it was, lo and behold it was the most decadent and rich sausage i've ever had, just spectacular.  i'm not really a squid person, but i've ordered it every time because it is so good.  the shallots in the salad too, i would eat those as a standalone dish.  the meatballs of course.  some friends could not stop talking about the artichokes and beets.  on the drink side, i never see cocktails based in armagnac, so i clearly had to try the zamboanga, and it did not disappoint.  just a great drink.  i could not leave without trying the house cappuccino, and like everything else, i found it highly enjoyable.  nicely done all around, we had high expectations and it did not disappoint.

t9ukoFO4EorEg5ZEXv_oCg.review_text: Unbelievable food. Jovial and warm environment. We had the roast chicken for two and it was easily one of the best things we've ever had. Incredible sauce, juicy and crispy--worth the wait!

epgLFdVaL--qAXyRJDs1XQ.review_text: After hearing/reading so many rave reviews about Tosca and the highly acclaimed new ownership, we had high expectations. Even some of my friends in NY were talking about this restaurant. There were a few good points but overall I'd say it was fairly average. I loved the atmosphere in the bar and the restaurant. It had a classy and fun vibe and lots of energy there. The dining area seemed small which I liked and I also liked the open view into the kitchen.  The service was above average. We had a lot of questions about the menu items since some of them are a bit different and our server was more than willing to help out. We stuck with beer and wine for alcohol. The wine list seemed a bit limited but I was able to find something satisfactory.  The food was hit and miss. It started out great, we started with the pickled veggies, a market salad, and the oxtail terrine. All three were above average. The best thing we had all night was the pasta dish. I forget what it was called but it had a lemon flavor and some toasted breadcrumbs. Very tasty. We ordered the lamb ribs and a nightly special veggie of turnips. These were  a letdown and a big miss. The problem was that the piece of meat was sooooo fatty. I'm not talking a little added flavor, it was almost inedible. The veggies were tasty but soaked in oil.  This seemed to be a bit of a common theme for all of the food. It was all too heavy/creamy/buttery/oily. You can serve heavier food without going overboard, but Tosca wasn't successful in doing this. I may go back for a drink at the bar or maybe try to order some different things, but I'd stay away from the lamb ribs or any veggies soaked in oil.

XIR1_GVjl2M2P9uit2kxpA.review_text: Pastas are amazeballs. They prefer that you order everything up front but will check on you later to see if you need anything. Tea is served in the same glasses as water (small lowball.) Lamb rib was pretty fatty but was good; turnips were oily and tangled, but asparagus was pretty good . Loved the cheese on top. Meatball appetizer was delicious.   Menu is a bit ... pompous and overthought; if it takes you 3 more esoteric food vocab words to explain one of the already esoteric food vocab words on the menu (aka, no one can really read your menu unless they are a chef at your level or a foodie who is heavily invested in speaking your chef language) ... you might want to rethink approachability.  Prices reasonable. Bathroom is clean, well-sized.

9AiwWbBKf040lti41-v9SA.review_text: We made a reservation 2 weeks in advance based on good reviews and hype.  Our reservation was for 5:15 PM, which we were told was the only available other than 11PM.  Despite how difficult the restaurant said it was to get in, we noticed many empty tables throughout our entire dinner.   The atmosphere was nice and the wine was good, but the food was so salty that it was nearly inedible.  We were "awarded" a complimentary dessert and coffee, which were, at least, not salty.    In sum, unless you are a camel searching for a mineral lick, don't eat at Tosca Cafe.

Sem3wD90eSvZ1K9GAKudMA.review_text: I was excited to come to Tosca's for a meal after reading all the rave reviews. Sadly, I was disappointed with the food. I thought all the dishes were too salty and simply not very good. Our waiter was pretty good though.

SdSFFy6GzpP7QZfT_HeDAw.review_text: A big disappointment.   First the loud music, not just loud but unmelodic and annoying.  Then the food, so overly spiced for every item ordered, and far from memorable.  Finally, a server mistake on a split salad resulted in our having to order an extra salad.  It appeared on the bill, with not even an acknowledgement or a gesture.   Too bad, because the waiters and the manager  were competent efficient and friendly, but the whole experience said loudly, I will not be back.

7zFA3EeZpSns6yLD1RClfQ.review_text: It had been a long family tradition to go to Tosca for a house cappuccino after a night on the town in San Francisco. We are from the valley and were anxious to try the new Tosca. First of all, the service was poor as we had to wait about five minutes to get service at the bar. It then took another five minutes to make our house cappucinos. I watched the woman in the white jacket make the drinks and use a measuring shot glass  (never a good sign !). The drinks came, tasted good but not as hot as I would have liked. When the bill came for $26.75 for the two drinks I realized that there must have been a mistake...hey, it happens.  Nope, no mistake; $12 for each drink, tax and, get this, a fee for using my credit card ! As it was not the bartenders fault for the rape, I left a tip - $30+ total ! Talk about getting "blanked" and not getting kissed ! Needless to say we won't be going back to this "new" San Francisco clip joint. The New Tosca will suffer for repeat business. Sort of like the touristy wax museum that kids beg their parents to go to; go once and never go back.  Tosca is done folks, the show is over.  I agree that Tosca should have folded the tent. Very sad. Keep your money in your wallet and head on down to the Buena Vista for an Irish Coffee for that hot after dinner drink!

Gh-g5zvP4i6tQKrMJZzfCw.review_text: Perhaps my expectations were too high. Was really happy that they started taking reservations tho. My friends and I had wanted to come here for awhile. Checked in at the host stand for an early res (5:15) and was told they would come and get us when it was time. Sat at the bar and ordered a very delicious cocktail - so far so good. It was past our res time by about 10 minutes and no one came to get us so we went back to the host stand and were seated in a nice rounded booth. Service was nice - I don't know why others are so critical.   The food is where the disappointment came for me. Had the pig tail app - delicious! Had meatballs - very good. Cesar salad - overdressed for me. I ordered the gemelli, done in the cacio a pepe style and it wasn't made correctly - very grainy with cheese instead of smooth. This is a dish I have had elsewhere better. The rigatoni was very good and the bucatini was tasty but the noodles were quite thin - bucatini should be thicker and chewier. hmmmm. Foccacia is delish and we had some broccoli that I didn't try and the potatoes.....too much food. Potatoes were a bit too salty for me.  Way too full for dessert but nothing on the menu seemed that inspiring anyway.   Glad I went but don't really need to go back. I find it interesting that this received such a glowing and high review in publications. Maybe when the chef/owner is there it's better but I don't get the idea she is there often. Maybe it was the chef de cuisines night off. Anyway.

O_kWf3jO95lqRWV0ZYE7dA.review_text: Had dinner late Sunday night, it was so good.  Portion sizes were perfect and hands down one of the best caesar salads I've had since moving to the city.  Definitely would recommend this place!

MsbIFptSdbUIBng23wFhbw.review_text: They did a slight renovation kept the old skool with a bit of new.  Great cocktails, great service and the food looked incredible.  Place was hopping.  Loved it.  Sure I miss some things they got rid of.....but they saved that place big time.  Real hand crafted cocktails.  Go there.

i_XzZXGrvAGFKNrwwCzF1A.review_text: We were out for a walk on a Saturday afternoon 1 week ago when, fortunately, we came upon Tosca at 4:45. The line had formed waiting for the door to open at 5. We had a nice social time in the line with co-line participants. The doors opened we went in and sat at the bar. This is what we intended. The bartender was very helpful with the menu and the recent background on the restaurant. My wife and I have been to the Spotted Pig and The Breslin in New York 2 of April's (the owner) restaurants. We do love both of the New York Restaurants. We were impressed with Tosca. At the bar we talked to the bartender and the people near us. A very friendly atmosphere.   We had the meatballs and the bar sandwich. The meatballs were a wonderful combination of meats and spices. They are worth the walk! The bread with the meatballs is wonderful and the bar sandwich was small but very good.   We will return!

9bWLc31bQvgxJfRH0lBzQg.review_text: One of my favorite things about San Francisco is that you really do not need to make reservations for some of the great restaurants our city has to offer, Tosca being one of them.  We arrived around 8pm and were told that it would be a 1.5 to 2 hour wait, but literally snagged two seats at the bar within 15 minutes.  I'm a big fan of April Bloomfield and was eager to see what she has done with the restaurant, so would not have minded the wait, regardless.  Besides, we were in no hurry and happy to have found a restaurant open on New Years night.    The atmosphere reminds me of a classic mobster movie, playing old Italian music, with dim lighting and dark booths as you pass the bar.  Very cozy, even sitting at the bar.  I was also very pleased with the service, as they were attentive despite how busy it was.    We started off our night with a cocktail to settle in, both of us ordering the Polo Cup (vodka, cucumber, mint, basil, elderflower, lemon soda).  Much care was taken to ensure they were made properly, as we watched our bartender beind the bar.  If you like cool, refreshing drinks like myself, this one definitely made an impression.  We ordered several dishes to share; my recommendations being the linguini with mussels, pancetta, and toasted coriander.  The combined flavors of the dish were excellent and the linguini cooked perfectly.  When I return to Tosca, this will definitely be a repeat.  Although I was disappointed that they ran out of the caulifower gratin, the crispy potatoes, prepared in pork fat, rosemary and garlic, did not disappoint.  And when you dip the potatoes in the remnant tomato sauce from the linguini dish?  Even better.  1 cocktail and 2 very generous glasses of wine later, how could you say 'no' to their House Capp (armagnac, bourbon and dandelion chocolate) and cannoli?  Perfect ending to a perfect dining experience...

fe7XWEvsP1h-wHStCx2GIw.review_text: This past friday came in with a couple of friends stood a few steps in the doorway not one person answers how many. Night was just beginning after that grab  a drink at bar then left. Gave in $43 for three drinks+tips. Enviroment was full of wanna be wall street banker type lol. Can't imagine this is happening it's a new place just open less than a month.

s3vjVl0K8y_UwYtZR7s_-A.review_text: I went to Tosca with friends on a Saturday night and found the atmosphere very pleasant. The bar wasn't too crowded and the ambiance was friendly. This review is because I received particularly good service from Henry who made sure my water didn't go empty even though he wasn't a server.

CilpDejgd6PPMSmWbBQkgQ.review_text: If the lamb ribs were't completely burnt and turned into charcoal, it would have gotten 3 stars. And if everything hadn't been over salted it would have gotten 4 stars. The only dishes that we had that weren't over salted was the baby octopus antipasti, and the pork sausage dish from the seconds section of the menu. The quality of the ingredients were wonderful, how ever the preparation was lacking a lot.   Not only was the food an issue for us, but the service was inattentive, not very helpful with ordering or answering questions, and it took forever to get seated and even longer to get our food. We arrived around 7:15pm and the hostess told us it would be a little more than an hour to be seated but probably less. We checked back with her at 8:30 and they still needed 30 minutes before we could get seated. In the end it took almost an hour longer than we were told it would take to get seated. Then we ordered. Our first dishes came in 10 or 15 minutes. But after that we had at least half an hour  gaps between courses while others who arrived after us had, in the meantime, been served 2 or 3 courses. We spent over 2.5 hours at Tosca; 80% of the time just waiting for service, food, or drinks.  I would not go back and would not recommend.

P-jv9v8gs5p0_hkA4o9Icw.review_text: The food is fantastic.  I can empathize with some of the negative reviews as this place can get so busy that it can detract from the overall experience.  My recommendation is to go early in the week close to opening and sit at the bar so that you skip the cluster this place can become at prime time.  Pro-tip; if you're tall, sit at the end of the bar closest to the door.  The bar bows out in the middle/toward the end and makes it tough if your legs are long.  You don't want to be hunched over your soup.  Speaking of soup, get the Italian Wedding Soup.  It's perfect and a must have.  Also, fried pig tails with balsamic reduction, yum!  This is another place where I think you get more bang for your buck and more interesting flavors by sticking with small plates.  The entrees are good, but my preference is the pastas and small plates.    If only the space was a little bigger and less hectic, but there isn't much they can do about that...

FLUY2FXFIQ_YOldZElK_Rg.review_text: Came here for happy hour and snacks. The remodel modernized this place without getting rid of its classic charm.  Cocktails and snacks were nice but unfortunately didn't have time for a main. Will be back to try those lamb ribs.   Looks perfect for a date in the back corner. Dark and romantic.

xjGlDn8juvva9IMrEeRn6Q.review_text: I took my sister here when she visited from Milan last month. Nice relaxed dining experience. Had the mod carding appetizer and olives. She had the lamb entree I had the fish. Scrumptious food and good service. Came back with coworkers for happy hour. The bartenders are friendly, professional and mix great drinks. I will go back

w1tI3Oh7GB-fUYzECYrnlQ.review_text: On the rare occasion when the culinary stars aline, walk-ins to the hottest restaurants in town are possible.   Last Saturday, during the height of the weekend dinner rush, I was able to walk-in to Tosca at 7pm and score a table of 4.   Dont ask me how. Maybe I can be that persuasive? ;)  I was ECSTATIC to eat here because I had just finished Season 2 of Mind of Chef" on Netflix and was really impressed with April Bloomfield's cooking style: fresh ingredients done simply or honest ingredients in unforgettable dishes.   The food lived up to my expectations and I really enjoyed my meal here:  The standouts: -Crispy pig tails: One of those dishes that are so good that you think, man, why hasn't someone done this before? A classic example of throw away bits that you can re-purpose into delicious dishes. Crunchy coating, succulent fat, and the carnal experience of eating with your hands and gnawing fat and cartilage from bone. So satisfying. -Rigatoni: One taste of this dish and you understand why Mario Batali flew her out from London to New York and offered her a job that day. This British girl knows her Italian. So simple, so delicious.  -Roasted chicken for 2 in marsala and ricotta bread: I wasn't a fan of the soggy ricotta bread under the roasted chicken, but the chicken itself and the marsala sauce was delicious. Moist, juicy, flavorful chicken and silky, decadent marsala sauce mingling with the jus of the chicken. Comfort food brought to another level.  -Crispy potatoes in pork fat: the perfect accompaniment to the roasted chicken. Perfectly crispy and slightly salty on the outside and creamy on the inside. Slight notes of herb.   Pretty good: -Grilled polenta with mushrooms, mascarpone, and parmesan -Artichokes in oil, red wine vinegar, aioli, mint and oregano  Pass:  -Oxtail terrine: strange dish for me. Cold, identifiable gelatinous substance solidified around meager chunks of oxtail.

w60IfM7aXw2L45uS1KBNJQ.review_text: Oh Tosca. We will be dreaming of your Spring Minestrone soup. So delicious that we went back 4 days later. I feel the Yelp ratings are a little lacking and probably a testimony to high expectations of a celebrity chef / angst over a SF legend. I have been to Tosca when it was just a super cool bar with a famous juke box, and now I've had the privilege of enjoying dinner twice. Most recently with April Bloomfield in the kitchen. And I was very satisfied.   The pastas are legit. Exactly what my Italian husband was looking for in terms of comfort food and taste. The soup was, well, let's just say I would pay money to get the recipe (hint). We also had the meatballs. Oh. My. God. A meat combo of pork shoulder, beef short ribs, and guanciale. GUANCIALE!! I don't get the overly salty thing mentioned by others. I thought all the seasoning was spot on. There were other amazing things like roasted carrots and broccoli, but I think you get the picture.   I thought the wine by the glass options were exciting. I love a Sicilian Frappato (trendy, I know, but I do). And there was an amazing red frizzante (lightly chilled) that was absolutely perfect for an abnormally warm SF night. I admit I am a fan of April Bloomfield, but I also do not tolerate a mediocre meal or service. I felt well taken care of. I will recommend to all my friends. And I hope you get to enjoy as well. Oh - I tried the house cappuccino. It was good. Yeah... I said it. It was real good.

MzXPOK2_T5O8GF-4qUVmGA.review_text: I've been going to Tosca for over 2 decades.  I've had a birthday party here, I even had a photo shoot here.  So, I, like a million or so others, eagerly awaited the reopening; & very much appreciated the interior upgrade that did not sacrifice the integrity of the original space.  It's been almost a year since the addition of dinner service, so time to review...  Oxtail terrine.  Thumbs down.  We did not care for this at all.  Too gamey & fatty, which is not a good thing for a cold dish.  Pass.  Egg Tonnato.  Fresh & different.  A boiled egg served chilled dressed w anchovies & served w tuna & lemon sauce w capers.    Bucatini.  The undeniable star of our dinner cast.  The sauce was zesty, spicy, & uber flavorful.  Absolutely delicious.  The pasta was cooked to perfect bite.  A must order.  Crispy potatoes.  Oh, wow.  Who doesn't love potatoes fried in duck fat?  Decadent & addictive, like the bucatini.  Do it.  Roasted carrots.  OMG.  These were the BEST CARROTS I've ever had in my life.  EVER.  So unexpected.  This dish won for best supporting actor in our dinner cast.  Even against the crispy potatoes.  A must.  The host was delightful.  Despite how busy it was, he was calm, cool, & collected.  Genuinely helpful & professional.  Nice.  Service can be spotty, but that's par for the course at most restaurants, unfortunately.  The server was flustered, but we ordered through the bar, & they were great.  There was a 45 minute wait between our cold apps & our dinner, but it was Friday night & a packed house.  When I brought it to the attention of our server, it was rectified immediately w finesse & positivity.  Impressive.  Another great night @ Tosca.

WBiBUFlN4BNp_VRbtQwSOQ.review_text: Really enjoyed our dinner at Tosca. Great cocktails, the linguini with mussels was perfect and the the chicken was well worth the hour wait! (It says on the menu that it takes an hour, wasn't due to slow service). Look forward to going back, will be hard not to order the chicken again. Plus, they play good music!

aPfvp1IInbpUkWHi6OLNrA.review_text: Tiny portions! Smaller than tapas!  $11, 3 teenie pieces of fried artichokes. $17, for a sliver of polenta and a few mushrooms $15, 3 teensy and very bitter meatballs. Weird. And barely sauced... What's the idea behind the food here?  Are you trying to feed us...or cheat us?!  Tony's does it better

-CdioCf2vBD_agBBW3NIww.review_text: Was at Tosca last night for the grand re-opening!  The place looks great!  It's different, but it's still real, still Tosca!  Maybe even better.  They serve food now, until 1am, no less, and wines are chosen by Randall Grahm, the master of Bonny Doon Vineyard! New owner Ken Friedman and his manager, Jennifer, presided and the doyenne of Tosca, Jeanette Etheredge, was there, positively glowing!  Brought my son in today for a superb Dandelion hot chocolate.  Looking forward to coming back again soon!  Good job, Tosca! And good luck!

o3PGs0t2a8ORb0gUXFr0bQ.review_text: Everything was amazing. The artichokes in oil are perfection.  The special rosemary focaccia delish.  I ordered gemeli with pecorino and pepper which is cacio e oepe.  And a side of broccoli di cecco.  So macaroni and cheese with broccoli.  And it was the finest ever made.  Wine list ... Italian heaven. Cannot understand the 3 star overall here.  Get a life.  April's menu is fantastic and the room is "preserved ".  Enjoy and rate responsibly.

o6Tm2BUCH38NwDWgdsLu8g.review_text: Well I ate here with my best friend after waiting for 3 months to finally have a night off together due to our crazy schedules. Ordered a lot because we like to go big. And heard from other chefs that this place is nice for late dinner (especially for industry people who get out late everyday like us). Anyways....like everything we got. Octopus was good. Cacio de pepe was too cheesy it was gloppy and not creamy. The tiramisu was perfect. The problem is here.....We got the chicken liver. We both love chicken liver. We are BOTH chefs here in SF.!! It came out and it was on a skewer. Took it off the skewer and noticed it was very medium rare.  Not the best idea to eat chicken liver so under done and we knew it. Not blaming tosca. We poked at it and talked about weather or not we should eat it. We ignored our better judgement and ate it cause we were so hungry. Finished our meal and went home. 5 days later I became extremely I'll from food Bourne illness aka food poisoning. To be honest I had no idea what it was from. I was in so much abdominal pain that I almost fainted twice. It lasted strong for 3 days. A couple days later after returning to work I texted my same friend and asked her when we can schedule our next meal together, that's when she said she has been bed ridden due to food poisoning. That's when my jaw dropped. I told her I had the same thing and it must have been our dinner from earlier in the week. We remembered the "if-y" liver we ate. I emailed tosca and told them what happened. Only seemed like the right thing to do. I wasn't blaming them And I wasn't mad or upset, but being in the food business I just thought it's something I should share. We would want someone to share that kind of info if it was our restaurants. It's been over a month and I haven't heard anything. No sorry. No thank you for sharing. No we will try to be on the look out for that. No nothing. So I took this time to write a yelp review to share my experience with people who actually care. Here it is. Enjoy everyone. Bed time.

3FJ4B-R4ejW0CyoUVw1KDw.review_text: I would have given the New Tosca Cafe more stars, however there was one major experience which marred the entire night for my wife and I.  To start, the ambiance when we walked in was amazing. There were tons of people, old-tyme jazz,  and an overall celebratory attitude. We've been here twice and the part that bothered both my wife and I was the chef, the head chef I believe. On both occasions he started yelling at the servers despite the fact that our service was on time and extremely hospitable. He just started berating the staff members like they were doing something wrong. It was like having a crazy person in the room. TOTALLY unprofessional.   I will be returning however I hope this guy isnt there.

eKUGKQRE-Ywi5dY55_zChg.review_text: Chef April Bloomfield is an awesome culinary bad ass. Only 1% of all Michelin chefs worldwide are female; she has two Michelin starred restaurants. Two! She was named Best Chef, NYC in 2014 by the prestigious James Beard Foundation. She's the highest scoring Iron Chef competitor who beat Iron Chef Vin Diesel (aka Chef Symon). AND, her newest restaurant, the revamped Tosca Cafe was named #4 in The Best New Restaurants in 2014 in America by Bon Appetit! It was only fitting to end the year with a bang and have our last meal of 2014 at a Tosca Cafe before KO at 9:30 pm and waking up 10 minutes before the countdown...only because I thought it was an earthquake. Come to find out it was just our puppy, Tater Tot furiously humping Mr. NSS' shoulder. I guess we know who's boss! Anyhow, the stars were aligned when we able to snag last minute reservations at Tosca Cafe and were seated in a cozy booth with front row seats to the kitchen. Reservations are a must on the weekends unless you have 2+ hours to kill. Tosca Café serves Italian food with a twist. The prices are really expensive for the small portions (hello, $4 for a chunk of bread!) but worth it. Prepare to spend about $80-$100 pp for food and drinks. ~ * ~ C O C K T A I L S ~ * ~ All cocktails are $12. *Polo Cup: bit.ly/1DftXBk *Choke Hold: bit.ly/1BDY8xO *Suffering Bastard: bit.ly/14sfbZB My fav was the Polo Cup because it's super refreshing. Choke Hold was super stiff. The Suffering Bastard was a bit too sour for my liking. ~ * ~ F O O D ~ * ~ Reading all the reviews complaining of the food being overly salty, we requested "lightly salted" for our order which was just right. *Pressed Pig Ear ($5): 3 STARS bit.ly/1xvMbeM Nothing special; reminded me of thinly sliced headcheese. *Crispy Pig Tails ($9): 5 STARS bit.ly/1tDFJwF These were phenomenal. Think super crunchy and juicy chicharrones. The drizzle of balsamic reduction perfectly cut through the richness. It was SO good that we ordered another round. *Meatballs w/ house baked focaccia ($12 + $4): 5 STARS bit.ly/14qkeKj These were disappointingly tiny but the flavorful meatiness and airy texture made up for it. The crunchy yet cloudy focaccia dipped in the marinara sauce was deliciously satisfying. *Lucamoni w/ prosciutto, treviso, lemon breadcrumbs ($17): 4 STARS bit.ly/1AxfL4r All their pastas are made in-house, and you must order one. The lucamoni had a great toothsome bite and I loved the light saltiness from the prosciutto and the crunchy texture contrast from the breadcrumbs but it was way too lemony. *Roasted Half Chicken For Two w/ ricotta, pine nuts, marsala ($42): 4.5 STARS bit.ly/1Ihkh7t For the price of 8.4 whole rotisserie chickens at Costco, you get a whopping half a chicken at Tosca Café...BUT, this roast chicken beats Zuni Café's hands down (their chicken is so boring and overrated)! The skin was lightly crisp and the meat was succulently moist; even the breast meat. The marsala sauce added a great complex savory sweetness. Loved the crusty bread topped with creamy ricotta and pine nuts. Best roast chicken ever but the price tag is just too ridonkulous to warrant 5 stars. *Crispy Potatoes w/ pork fat, garlic, rosemary ($7): 2 STARS bit.ly/1xLmnNg People raved about this but our order oddly tasted like bitter, burnt garlic. *Tiramisu ($9): 4 STARS bit.ly/1xvNt9u This tiramisu will rock your taste buds. The espresso flavor is super strong; way too strong for me but it was well-executed and nicely fluffy.     ~ * ~ S E R V I C E ~ * ~ This would be a 5 star review except the staff is cold and the service very slow (we had 5 pm reservations). The only friendly people in the army of staff are the hostess and the American Indian waitstaff (super nice guy). Hopefully one day their kindness will rub off on the rest of the other staff. Obviously, it's their job to get sh*t done and they do but a little kind reciprocation would be appreciated. They wouldn't even acknowledge our "thank you"s. Don't expect them to ask you how your meal is either. Our meal was coursed out so there was an unbearably long lag between courses. Dinner took over 2.5 hours for 4 courses so liquor up! Only knocking off a star for service because we expected this given all the other reviews. ~ * ~ A M B I A N C E / D E C O R ~ * ~ Dark, old skool, and insanely loud. There's 6 tight booths, 3 four tops, 4 two tops, and a private room in back for large groups. Not recommended for an intimate date. ~ * ~ P A R K I N G ~ * ~ Insanely difficult street parking which is why I normally avoid the area. They need to offer valet parking.

4iFx8XlmOFJ1fg93ctFqVA.review_text: Wow I can't believe I have written a review of Tosca yet! This place is amazing. Food is so unique, it never seems to disappoint. The menu does change a bit which is good since I am forced to try different items. The first time I dined here, they had clams in a vegetable broth. One of the best dishes I've eaten in a while. The roasted chicken was worth the hour wait. I get a little carried away with ordering here so why the time the main course shows up, ie an entire chicken, my stomach is reaching the full point. Moscardini is also on the top of my list here. Cocktails are also tasty!  Bring a friend and share everything! You will have a great expereince.

3Kn05dbSYgsEFxad7oETBQ.review_text: The vibe is very elegant and modern.the food is to die for especially the meat balls and focaccia bread. The service is very quick and helpful,the kitchen is very open so you can watch your food being made.its a perfect place to be if you want a early dinner because waits aren't long yet.the dim chandelier lighting and old fashioned booths add a great effect .

oHOInzaXWM7uJIni498auQ.review_text: Do not order the chicken. I waited about 2 hours to be cooked when I was told that it would take about an hour. As more than an hour passed, I was hoping that it would be worth the wait. When it finally arrived and I tasted it, I was extremely disappointed. I ate about 10% of it and that was too much. The chicken seemed uncooked, and had no taste. Do not waste your time and money on the chicken.

nYDozThOT6SxLzLQC8U14A.review_text: Bring back the Old Tosca.  This new version has tampered with tradition.   It is also too expensive.

t6dnI9F0_MyLKNCxI591RA.review_text: I'm surprised the reviews here aren't higher -- I had the most delicious experience from start to finish.  The hits? - Lumaconi:  wonderful bites of large shell pasta with lemon breadcrumbs and prosciutto, bathed in cream sauce - Bucatini:  perfectly al dente in a hearty tomato/guanciale sauce.  Order this with a side of meatballs - Grilled Lamb Ribs:  fall-off-the-bone, tender, flavorfully marinated and nicely complemented by marinated grilled onions - Focaccia:  sop it all up with a tall, fluffy slice  Oh, and if you have space, the gelato is perfect!  The downside is you won't get the predictability from being able to reserve in advance, but if you happen to be passing by and there's no crowd, Definitely worth a stop!

65M53Vg0LxmvPx31oYzFZA.review_text: Delicious plates with poor service and inflated prices dragging the star level down to 3.  My date and I show up as walk-ins on a Wednesday. The bar is hopping, but there are plenty of 2 person tables open. The hostess informs us she can seat 2 but she cannot accommodate our friend if she decides to join (despite many open 2 tops) - minus points.  Service starts off well - attention to the water glasses, folding napkins after the restroom... But then it starts to slide quickly. Our waitress informs us that we must make a complete order... What? We were never given bread and then the water refills started to slip.   We started with the baby octopus. Outstanding! I didn't know it was possible to get such a wonderful texture from octopus.  The tuna salad with radish was bright and full of flavor, very refreshing.  The salmon entree was exquisitely prepared, it had a dual personality that was completely balanced between sashimi and cooked. The crispy skin on top was the icing.   We ordered two espressos and this is where service really fell off. Plopped the espresso down without a plate, no sugar, no espresso spoon- had to ask for these items. On top of that the espresso was terrible! Bitter, and not in the strong espresso way! But in the, omg this is almost inedible way (even with 3 scoops of sugar)!

UZRMPhyWEPqyiGJaTjrWLA.review_text: The cocktails are delicious, albeit expensive, but do not go here for dinner unless you want to pay a lot for very little in terms of quality and service.  We were told there was a 10 minute wait, then waited an hour for a table with no apologies from the hostess. As other reviewers mentioned, the dishes are tiny and unimpressive.  They even undercooked the pasta.  Getting charged for bread adding insult to injury, especially since the only redeeming part of the meal was the slightly sweet gravy with the overpriced half chicken.  The waiter was very attentive about asking us whether we wanted more drinks or dessert, but never checked on the quality of the food or gave us any useful recommendations.  I hope that Tosca figures this out, as it is a great little historic bar with potential.

BlCLKtUfNErckfM1ULvBOw.review_text: Reunion with an old friend from Shanghai!  Love the atmosphere-it's reminiscint of NYC

KUusL15g7gVmPO7_XRp8cQ.review_text: * absolute mind blown..  From our apps: marinated olives, fennel, octopus, chicken liver toast.. To the chicken for two. Wao. Soooooooo yummy!!!  Service was on point, our bottle of Chardonnay Nebbiolo was insanely delicious and so was the chocolate ganache cappuccino with bourbon that ended my meal on cloud 9.  What a wonderful little gem. Will definitely be back!!!

OTCxrFVCPN5vZH09kxIj9w.review_text: Terrible is all I can say. No ports to offer? And the prices for their whiskey offerings are ridiculous.  I was at three other bars in SF this week that offer Pappy for considerably less....  The service was awful as well. We waited at the bar for at least 10 minutes and not a peep from either bartender. This was on Wednesday.  It was busy, but not packed.   I thought the "Spotted Pig" influence was going to make this place better. We do look forward to eating here soon, so perhaps a redemption is possible in the near future.

kcNaMdowMzX8mKlWGlvjBw.review_text: Lovely spot, great bar, excellent service.  But, the food is overly salted.  Every dish:  the salad, 3 pastas we ordered, the roasted chicken, the focaccia, several appetizers were salted beyond belief.  Totally unnecessary, ingredients were good and they could stand alone but why so much salt.  We told our waiter no salt after the first few dishes, but everything is prepared in advance, ie pasta sauce and sauce for chicken, dressings. So we said no final dusting of salt which maybe they  did.  But it was terrible, will not go back.  Will go for a cocktail at the bar but not for dinner

wHxQxNbNbWQQdIKhWpWb-Q.review_text: Food was amazing. Pasta and meatballs, and the brioche bread were out of this world. We got lucky and walked in at 9pm on a Saturday & got sat in 10 min.

kMLbPSkqNjquPvt2kB6OIA.review_text: First time since the re-do.  Looks great and I don't know that I've had Italian food this  good in years.  Had the meatballs (extraordinary, not your typical lump of tasteless meat, but complicated flavors and great sauce); bucatini (perfectly cooked pasta with a rich (not too rich) sauce with little bits of pork and crunch...superb); and a side of broccoli di cicco (if you're going to eat a vegetable, this is the way to eat it...again, perfectly cooked and seasoned, actually sort of complex).  Finished with buttermilk gelato, which was perfect.  The cocktails (negroni) were nice, too.  A tad pricey; but the serving sizes are just right.  We sat in the backroom (who knew?) and it was quieter, if a tad stuffy (air-wise).  Only complaint was that, while the staff are on the whole friendly and helpful, our waitress was a tad chilly...but we'll be back.

XvypNyl5nA227YBk4KJFdQ.review_text: This is one of those places you hear people RAVE about.  Popped in around 6pm. It was PACKED. No greeting. Found a seat at the "wall bar" with trash near by.  Ordered one of these whisky coffee drinks. One with and one without alcohol? Maybe it's because I prefer my coffee black.. but it was pretty disgusting mix of coffee and milk and I don't know what. Maybe they had a good menu in the dining area.. but I don't think I'll be going back. Not with all the other options near by.   Snooty and crowded was my memory of the place.  But if you like loaded milky coffee drinks with whisky in super crowded bars! This is the place for you!!

lHeAyj_7kSVakMMHDT5ORA.review_text: I used to live in North Beach and loved the old Tosca Cafe for drinks.  When I returned to SF for a visit, I wanted to check out the spot's new life as a restaurant with a much talked about offering.  The interior has not changed much except for more lighting and a window into the kitchen as well as some wall decor.   I was hoping they'd soften the ambient noise some how but the dining room still has a dark diner feel to it.  They could improve on this.  Regarding the food, it was delicious...when it finally arrived (a tease about the service which I'll cover later).  The bread for the table came warm and tasty.  We had to rip it apart so would suggest they partially score it.    Then, we got the Italian wedding soup and it was solid - light w/ yummy meatballs / pasta.  We also ordered the grilled polenta and gemelli.  Highly recommend the polenta.  A burst of interesting flavors and nicely presented.  The gemelli was ok.  Nothing good; nothing bad.  Lastly, was the trout.  Solid execution.  Overall, the food was great. Would give food 3.5 stars.  As for the service, it's clearly something they are still working on.  We arrived and the hostess was not the warmest.  When we were seated, about half the dining room was full...yet, it took quite some time for our server to get our order and then, for the food to come out.  As I sat from our banquette, I could see the dining room fill up and once that happened, the slowness became obvious.  It seemed like the crew was overwhelmed a bit.  Would give service:  2.5 stars.  It needs improvement.

V5Th21KjUiYLJQyV-vGtpg.review_text: I didn't get to have a drink at Tosca because the bar was super packed.  We ended up going somewhere next door.  The place seems like a step up from the dive bar competition all around them.  I stared at a loaf of foccacia bread on the bar counter for at least a minute because I was hungry.  It looked so good and I was hungry at the time FYI.  It's not often during my Friday night drink hopping trips that I get intrigued into finding a place that I want to try their food.  I definitely know now that this is a popular nightspot so I'll definitely make sure to try their food and drinks and subsequently update my review later on...

8BWHn8BNHtRW4rbzFc3u5w.review_text: Well I was underwhelmed. Hard to compete with all the press and live up to the expectations. We arrived, 4 of us, at 5:15. Drinks at the bar took a solid 10 minutes. Thankfully, they were excellent.   Our waiter was too soft-spoken and it was difficult to understand him. We ordered pig tail, fennel, oxtail terrine, 2 pastas, meatballs, fried anchovy, and tuna conserva. All were solid. There were complaints that the pastas and meatballs were under-seasoned. I loved the chili that came through.  I would say the biggest flaw was service. I ordered another drink at the table and it simply never arrived. They also sent us the wrong pasta dish, and they never once checked on the table to ask how the food was.   Expect more from April & Ken by reputation. Love their NYC restaurants.

rzPH0MaG7MMS2IPEAr1dqw.review_text: The new Tosca is effing FANTASTIC! I dont really like playing this card, but Im going do it: Im an old timey, fifth generation San Franciscan. I know there's been lots of discussion about the old Tosca closing and new one opening, but guys -- we're incredibly lucky to live in a community that cares about its history, its bars, its restaurants, its haunts with such fierce loyalty . San Francisco thrives because of the constant populations streaming through the golden gates to build a life they simply couldnt build anywhere else. And thank god the team coming into Tosca 1. care about great food 2. know how to cook it well.  We had the meatballs, the oxtail terrine, the octupus antipasta -- to die for. Roasted cauliflower and the roasted chicken -- what a diva. That chick steals the show, and well worth the 45 min slow roast wait. Each piece is succulent and perfectly evenly cooked. Absolutely amazing.  Cocktails were delicious and I love the glasses. My sister got the cappucino, and it was truly amazing...   The decor is fantastic. Red vinyl been replaced by red leather, but my fave is definitely the bathroom -- the coral tile that seems to have been the standard pre-war, and my dad and brothers proudl confirmed Marilyn's still in the boys room. I personally love the library ladder on the south wall used to grab bottles of wine.  thank god Tosca is still around! thank god they took such care to maintain the character. Most of all, thank god the food is so delicious and done with such care! times, they are always a' changing. Tosca, glad you're still around!

PB8DShHIsOw7A2iFnF-LMQ.review_text: First time back since the redesign. Went there a few years ago after hearing great things about their drinks. I had an amazing dirty martini and loved the character of the bar. Went back yesterday and have never been so disappointed in my life.  Ordered a dirty martini and the bartender says 'we don't have dirty martinis.' Wait, what? I pressed the issue a little and asked why a cocktail bar couldn't a very basic drink (vodka, vermouth, olive juice) and she was extremely rude, basically yelling and belittling me and telling me 'I'm SO sorry we can't appease you but that's just the way it is so if you don't like it you can leave'  Needless to say I will NEVER be coming back, to what used to be a favorite North Beach hang out.

GnaVGdKi7MF-vkO-Z25qTQ.review_text: Went here last night for dinner.  Very nice space and setup, would love to return for a drink and small bites, but food just okay.  Prices are high but not out of the range for SF. Had crispy pig tails, meatballs, Dungeness crab salad, Bucatini and Gemelli, Tiramisu for dessert. Overall everything was overseasoned. Bucatini was salty but decent, while Gemelli had about 90% of a lethal dose of salt. Tiramisu had enough orange zest and liqueor to lack any appreciable taste other than that. Overall, most things weren't that balanced; with a lighter touch I bet they would have been really good. Nowhere near as good as other Italian places in the price point and nearby, like Cotogna or Perbacco.   Digression: Arrived about 515, wanted to start with cocktails and small plates, but waitress said we'd have to order everything at once.  Little strange for a bar/restaurant, especially when we wanted to space a couple of cocktails over the meal.  Most places seem to prefer it the other way, to order drinks first and have those arrive before ordering food so that you'll order more booze over the course of the meal. Apparent attempt to turn over tables quickly at expense of enjoying meal and drinks. Which I guess is fine, but just interesting the way she refused our request to start by ordering our appetizers first.

1oZYTtix-ewdp7gKMu4BGA.review_text: We really wanted to like this place, but it was just a bad experience all the way through. 4 of us put our name in around 6:30 and were told 45 minutes. No problem though, the place was crowded and we totally anticipated a wait. We went to a bar across the street and came back/ checked in with the hostess after 40 minutes. She told us we'd be the next couple of groups seated. 20 minutes later, we saw we had a missed call from the hostess, who we were literally standing 3 feet from and had at this point checked in twice with. Apparently she had completely forgotten who we were and passed us over on the list-- long story short, we waited 2 hours to be seated, instead of the quoted 45. The only reason we stuck around was because we were starving and a little tipsy after some strong drinks at the bar.
