We explained the situation to the waitress and said we were disappointed with the experience thus far, and she mumbled some lame excuse about the previous party taking a while to (not relevant to our situation, we were repeatedly passed over on the wait list). Their sorry attempt at appeasing us was to bring a free (gross) cold vegetable plate-- would have been more appreciative of some comped drinks. Sadly, the situation didn't improve-- drinks took 20 minutes to arrive, and the grilled lamb ribs we all ordered were 90% fat. Only highlights were the brussel sprouts and the foccacia (which we devoured in our starved state). Went home hungry and disappointed! Hope others have better luck.

U32PUYeupHWju0e9PUEU_A.review_text: The food here is no good and way overpriced (sound familiar for North Beach?). Had two pasta dishes, forgettable (that's why I can't recall them here). Put to top it all off, it was my birthday and a friend brought me a cupcake. After a struggle, the waiter brought the cupcake back with a candle. Upon getting the bill, he charged a $7 "cakeage fee" for doing nothing more than sticking a candle in. No plates, cutting, etc. Needless to say, he took the charge off, but just a pretty below-average experience overall.

sIt0zmHkelTevuvkM55ImA.review_text: Maybe I'm just disappointed...I have very fond memories of the old Tosca...Unassuming, delicious and reasonably priced prohibition era drinks.  They have LITERALLY doubled in price, since I last visited.  You can't even sit at a table anymore,  unless you're having dinner. Why'd they have to make it all snooty? The House Cappuccino, used to be awesome, now it's super sweet and way fancier, the servers made sure I knew, but sorry, the expensive ingredients don't make it taste better. And the charm it used to have is gone. The food is very good, yes, but it's basically a completely different restaurant now, not a charming neighborhood bar, and I miss the old Tosca, where I'd spent hours drinking and chatting with friends and loved ones.  Sadly, my husband and I won't be back. Unless we're ready to drop 25 bucks on 2 drinks!!!

97YdD8tkMkUSvGUw6_u4GQ.review_text: this place is way too loud and crowded for Friday night. it reminded me of those crowded New York places that I came to dread since I moved to San Francisco. Better check it out on a weeknight.  the murals on the wall were quite impressive, reminding one of the renaissance height of Italian art without being too pretentious. Good collection of cocktails and the food was quite delicious. We ordered the fried artichoke where small pieces were lightly battered with some capers to counter the slight grease.   If one could chase the crowds away, this place would be perfect!

zYxeaO2gDxS1eIZ_3pE1iQ.review_text: Get your act together in terms  of service.  I know I'm gonna sound like an old fart since I've been coming to Tosca for over Thirty years but if I'm ordering food at the bar the first fuckung thing you ask for is my cc card ? Manners baby. I get it if I'm standing w drinks but sitting and eating!  Good food but aside for the woman bar tender the guys don't give a shit.  Smile !

UHfB_MWtZnK8UB_WhmK0wg.review_text: I am not sure why there are so many negative reviews for Tosca, we had a great meal and wonderful and attentive service.  We will be back soon and often!

2dPE2x2ILv9-IkndQwo1vA.review_text: Went last night w/ 2 restaurant biz pals - WE LOVED IT! Every item of food was dee-lish...our server Tyler was fabuloso...great cocktails & wine (you can order a half glass:)...old ambiance with new energy. Here's what we had...fried artichokes, mussel soup, focaccia to get every last drop of that soup, Point Reyes blue salad, roasted chicken, and every one of the vegetables; broccoli di cicco, roasted cauliflower (my fave), crispy potatoes w/ garlic, baby beets w/ walnut pesto and then finished the feast with upside down pear cake (boozy).  It was Friday night busy, but we got a table with no wait...not sure how long that will last. It was noisy, but we expected that and parking was tough, but we expected that too.   So glad that Tosca is back in fine form and I hope Jeannette Etheredge is proud!

k-uAx-Cwq0R-rDcxm6VjRQ.review_text: It was good not great.  And I wanted it to be great since I enjoyed the Spotted Pig so much when I went there.  The pastas are decent. We had the gemelli, the rigatoni and the special pasta, which turned out to be our favorite. It was something with cheese and cream but honestly, I can't remember the specifics because those drinks are so strong! And good.   The chicken though. For 42 dollars you are hoping for an amazing chicken. Nope. I still can't figure out why it's 42 dollars.  So, while I'd go back because the space was beautiful and the bartenders were attentive (we sat at the bar), I wouldn't wait in a line or go out of my way to eat here but be prepared to spend some money and also, it gets crowded.

4oJemmxW2uyRCJRH1p9niA.review_text: The Bucatini is seriously special.  I find bacon to be so overused on so many menus, but April has some delicious skills when it comes to guancale.  Somehow the pork face gets soft, succulent and crispy, all at the same time.  But the porkiness is subtle as to not over power the dish.  When you don't have a bite of pork, you get a rich, spicy, tomato bite of pasta.  The chili works well to power down the pork, and adds a whole new layer to finish off the dish.  The dish is salty, spicey, and rich.  In my mind it's the perfect pasta.  The bartenders here are great, they truly care about their craft.  I waltzed a little after 5pm, so seating was not a problem at all.  If this pleace gets crowded and you have to wait long, there is nothing the restaurant can do about it!  That should not impact your review at all.  If you don't like the subtle changes in the restaurant, then you're crazy.  It's beautiful in there.   I would stay away if it's over-jammed in there, get here at an off time and enjoy the well crafted food.

h0FPJR1jCDpwq0C4t8ArLA.review_text: After reading a thousand rave reviews for the newly revamped Tosca - I had to give it a try.  The bar opens at 5, and we arrived at 5:30. Good thing, because the bar seating was already full. Good to see!  For our first round we ordered the House Cappuccino and a Polo Cup with gin. The House Cappuccino tastes incredible. Hot, luxurious and just boozy enough to make you fall in love.    The Polo Cup was decidedly unpleasant. I usually love a cocktail with lots of different flavors - and I'm a sucker for any drink that combines cucumber, mint and citrus - but this combination just didn't work for me. Alas. Maybe with vodka next time instead?  We split the charcuterie plate to munch on while we sipped our drinks. It was a surprisingly hefty plate and a great pairing to our drinks. The pickled veggies were amaze.   Excited to go back!

76j5wa3rZJt96K90PkFoUg.review_text: We had a large group and needed to push tables together but they were uneven. The manager insisted that we have even tables and moves their tables around to accommodate our group. We didnt mind but it was not up to us. Both our server and manger were delightful. I can't say enough good things about their service and professionalism. Raising the bar for north beach and booze coffee everywhere.

dkYcB0yD0Fx_r0mhGBFzUQ.review_text: Had reservations for two then last minute had another couple join us, the host was very accommodating. We all grabbed a drink at the bar then were escorted to our table, we were greeted very quickly the server was lovely and on point. Every thing came out in great timely fashion and he never missed a beat. Everything from the drinks to the appetizers to the main dish to our cappuccinos were splendid. I have been back since and it didn't change, service and food were outstanding...

Ap2OKYiipmm3hITXsjMZCQ.review_text: Atrocious service.  We showed up at 7:30 and were told we would be texted as soon as a table opened up.  We went to a bar down the street and received a text a half hour later.  After immediately responding and heading back to Tosca, we were told that there had "been a mixup" and that a table would not be ready for another hour.  We then waited an hour and a half during which time one member of our party was spilled on with a burning beverage by a drunk person at the bar. . . that the staff recognized and promptly ignored.  When we were finally seated, no recognition whatsoever was given to the fact that we waited as long as we did for a table.  To put a cherry on top of the lovely evening: the majority of our party ordered the steak, and rather than being asked how we would like it served, it was automatically served vastly undercooked. We couldn't believe the service would be so bad. As recent ex-New Yorkers, we can say that a patron at the Spotted Pig would never be treated so poorly.

OB5DYt6yVwYuTSaSYYWoxg.review_text: I really don't believe in sighing in print unless you're truly sighing and not just playing for effect. Sigh.   Prologue: I happen to like April Bloomfield's cookbook very much. Her food is hearty, smart, and well conceived. While I realize she is neither in the kitchen nor creating the menu top to bottom, I do believe this is wholly her method and her essence. At Tosca, the food is *all* seasoned heavily - taken right to the brink of being too salty. This is actually a great plus because it's hard to reach and easy to pass that salt line into failure. None of this or the previously noted contributed to the failures of our meal.  We started with the meatballs, which were not on the regular menu but an app special for the night. There were three nice meatballs in a shallow plate of well seasoned marinara. A nice start.  The focaccia too was well seasoned - again, almost too well seasoned - but very tasty. This is not the focaccia I grew up with on the East coast, but that was many years ago. Our waitress said we would love the focaccia to dip into our marinara, but that did not prove necessary (or true).  Next, the crispy pig tails, which I'd never tried before. My guess, they're braised/boiled until soft and then deep fried - the result is a pig tail chicken wing. Except they're fattier and stickier than a chicken wing and the meat is not as easily discerned as it is on a chicken wing. Part of that is due to the darkness of the room, but it's also due to the nature of the cut. No matter, such was its unctuous deliciousness that I chewed it down to almost nothing (which I do not do with a chicken wing). They were not dressed with anything and they were delicious. The highlight of the evening.  Alas, the mid-point of the meal is where all went awry.  First, the fritto misto - butter clams, padron peppers, and salsa gribiche. The most unforgivable problem was that it was served with our pasta dishes. There was a lull after the pig tails when the fritto misto should have been served. Served with the pasta, we had to set the pasta aside because soggy fritto misto is merde. Second problem, the clams were a little too tough. Third problem, either it was a mistake or intentional, but one of the battered pieces was a piece of lemon. This may be a delicacy to some, but I found it repellant and spit it out. The gribiche was okay but it didn't matter because of all the rest.  Then as quickly as we could go to the quickly cooling pasta...  Sigh.  The gemelli, my dish, was in the style of Cacio E Pepe ('cheese and pepper' - pecorino and grated black peppercorns), one I adore. It was over cooked, over-cheesed, and the sauce had seized and separated. Terrible. The proportion of pecorino to pasta was all wrong. I happen to put too much cheese on most of my pasta so for me to complain about it here is (almost) stunning. In addition to that, the sauce tasted lemony - so maybe they added lemon (which is not Cacio E Pepe), I don't know, but it was dreadful. As to the pasta itself, I absolutely demand al dente. Yes, the pasta was briefly set aside to pick through the fritto misto, but this pasta was too soft because it came out overcooked.  The date had the linguini with mussels, pancetta, and toasted coriander. The date is a soft touch who likes almost everything she tries in a nice establishment like this one. Her pasta was not as overcooked as mine, but she said the sauce was so sour and nasty that it tasted like vomit. Seriously, she said vomit. I have never heard her describe anything like that before. I tried a bite and it *was* vomitous - it had the raw, uncooked taste of poor quality tomatoes right out of a can. Sour like bile - hence, vomit.   Okay, so the pasta experience was awful - so awful that I actually complained to our waitress. This is also a first. I swear on the lives of all the puppies in the world that I have never done anything like that before. To the restaurant's eternal credit, they took both dishes off our bill. In retrospect, we ate almost none of either so that just makes sense - but I certainly did not expect it and I respect the integrity of the staff to make this decision without my request.  Some might say that every restaurant can have a bad night. I don't care. I don't have the time, inclination, or money to care - as professionals, I really don't think a restaurant deserves a bad night - or at least as bad as this one was at points in the evening.  In closing, but for the pasta dishes, this would have been a fine experience. The space is great, it's charming to see how they fit an open kitchen in there, the cannoli was very good, the house 'Cappuccino' still a treat, the service very good, and the cocktails quite excellent. This is why I cannot go below 3 stars.

fvM08uRbB6-jobLMEkfhAw.review_text: Oof. We wanted to love this place. My boyfriend raved about the bar it used to be. In its new incarnation, it was pretty sad.  1. Ordered wine and a cocktail. Wine came right away, with a ton of sediment in the bottom, and the cocktail came 15 minutes later.   2. Ordered the chicken liver, which came out fast and was the highlight of the event.  3. 50 minutes later our one pasta dish had still not arrived.   4. Ordered an old fashioned, which came 10 minutes later almost HALF full, including the enormous (we're so fancy) ice cube. So it was basically two sips for $12. I like to think they spilled most of it and just sent it out anyway.  5. Switched to a chianti, which came out ICE cold. Like, your hands are too cold to hold the glass cold.   6. The pasta dish we waited so long for was: Gemelli, black pepper, pecorino toscano. That is fancy talk for mac & cheese. Now I know. I huffed it in 45 seconds and then wondered if it would be another hour until we ate again.   7. For a main I ordered the pork sausage with squash, brown butter & sage. Thank god for that squash b/c it was very good and could be used to mask the sausage, which was moist in a really odd way. It almost had the consistency of a pate.   8. For dessert, instead of getting out of there, we ordered gelati and a coffee drink they're all proud of. Ten full minutes after we had finished the gelati, the coffee came.   We were there for two hours. There were so many missteps along the way, both in service and in food.   My least favorite part of the event actually happened twice, to my surprise. This was that the waitstaff smeared food ONTO our table as he attempted to be fancy and wipe up crumbs. It was so gross.   TL; DR: slow service, weird food, bad at drinks, smeared food onto the table twice.

lfFmv3vZAflRnFMywEKu9g.review_text: Overall we did not enjoy our meal.   Positive: The olives, wine, and cocktails. The specials were tasty: a rigatoni dish with fresh tomato sauce and mozzarella and focaccia.   Negative: Too loud for conversation. The service was inexplicably slow. The chicken liver skewers had an off flavor and were not cooked through as we had requested (served medium-rare). The linguine with clams was bitter. The salmon was far too salty. The roasted carrots were overly sauced and underdone.  An unfortunate dining experience for 2 locals and 2 visiting from out of town.

7v8H8b03IUNBDVl_bSy7KA.review_text: The food is great but the staff is truly lacking. We asked to be put on the list for a table (and were happy to wait) but the hostess (seemed very inexperienced) failed to advise she would text us but not walk the 10 feet to get us. No problem, we decided to eat at the bar. Except the distracted bartender forgot to put in our order (until we asked about our order an hour later and watched him put it in without apologizing). Overall, stressful three plus hour dinner at the bar. So sad given the quality of the food.

tSp5RGbfoVcjZUWZPrU6eA.review_text: Tried the new Tosca and will NEVER go back. Took over 25 minutes to get a drink and it was so watered down and expensive...and it wasn't even that busy as it was before 6pm. Food menu is so uninspiring and too expensive. Go to North Beach Restaurant if you want good food or any of the many other great restaurants with outdoor cafes and character in North Beach.

L4i0pVaeXgMSCcD3vyXplQ.review_text: Very very disappointing. It still looks great. And the Booths are fun. So its a great setting but the food ranged from mediocre to poor. Fatty lamb. Undercooked fish. Overcooked potatos. With so many great places to eat in SF this place just isn't worth it. It was better as a bar. Good Italian wine selection but the food menu is poorly conceived and not well executed

OtbooagsCGPM00ZbDOyPgw.review_text: What is the best way to describe the Tosca Café? It's a legendary stop in San Francisco's North Beach that any native and quite frankly any tourist has to hit the next time they are walking the famous Columbus Avenue.   My friend and I arrived at 5:30pm on a Friday evening and the place was already packed. (And they only opened at 5pm!) It was loud and the crowd was a we bit tipsy already. By the time we left by 7pm the place was hot, suffocating, extremely loud and absolutely overflowing with people. A place with the narrow bar all the way in front and the main dining room in the back does not provide for great aesthetics (or great breathable air for that matter), but then again this place is well, shall we say, "vintage" so like a fine wine we should celebrate the fact that it's still alive and kicking with providing great drinks and delectable dishes.    We managed to weasel ourselves two barstools to drinks and food. As for drinks since we were at the bar, my friend and I had try Tosca's world famous "House Cappuccino" a hot totty if I've ever had one before. It was rich and strong, just like I thought it would be. For the bar bites, we decided to try the roasted beets with pesto, the Frito Misto with clams and prawns, and the grilled polenta with heirloom radicchio. My friend said it best when she declared it was "one of the best meals" she's ever had in her life. Quite the high praise Tosca's. I too found Tosca Cafe's menu delightful and rich with flavor and meaning. Star chef April Bloomfield's menu has clearly has a purpose and it's not just geared towards the casual tourist or barfly.   So that's a very good thing. Since the place is so popular now it tends to fill up very fast and gets loud even faster. The place is popular now with locals and tourists alike. In this case, the place is no longer the romantic gem of North Beach. But still I plan on returning in the future, so I can sample their pasta dishes and more of their flavorful bar bites.

WeWbt17LJ40HGGEOW_7qrw.review_text: Complaints about wait and prices are understandable, to a point. You people stay away and those of us willing to enjoy a cocktail or two at the bar before being seated will stretch a bit financially and have a terrific meal and an extraordinary evening. One of SF's unique places.

9Jc9yJ3EbCP0ancpazHBfQ.review_text: Would have given a 5 except Darren K the server was far from the sharpest tool in the shed.   He knew the menu in detail but his ability to forget to deliver items was amazing, he wasn't overworked as there are plenty of staff, he just didn't show up mentally and would often disappear.  Were it not for the bus boy helping him, last night would not have been a great experience.  Food AMAZING though.  Hopefully the owners are reading, basic training and monitoring of customers at tables will fix this, will be back for sure.

2s6DVB4YgDyDuNX_FbAHFQ.review_text: One word....Jordan! That's all you need to know if you plan to eat here. My girlfriend and I ate here on our last night in San Fran. Our waitress (Jordan) was fun, and kept us highly satisfied the entire time with drinks and food. Not to mention, she's not bad to look at. If you're looking for a good date this is the place to go. I recommend the big tails as a starter. In fact, I just recommend you eat as much as humanly possible at this place. It's just that good. Way to go Jordan, cheers to you for Making our last dinner so awesome.

jKb91dWICYsTaN567XJCnA.review_text: Salty. We ordered a lot of food and every dish was over salted.  I left with my lips burning and a pretty bad stomach ache.  Honestly the food seemed really good on the menu, and the pork dishes were pretty delicious had it not been so salty! We didn't even order dessert just in case that was also over salted.  Very disappointing meal. The ambience also didn't help, I am not a fan of a place where the staff makes it feel stuffy and uptight.

RKfETgoe0wuZds8EMDBw0Q.review_text: This place considers itself rustic italian.  Not sure what that means except it was interesting to try the pigs tail.  Also had a polenta dish.  Not sure why I got it since I am not a polenta fan.  Wanted to give it a try but did not like it.  Turnips however were great.   The bar tender was top notch.  I went for the tenders choice and we got two creative drinks.  One was the chokehold.   Wish I remembered what was in it but it was good.  The other drink was Hotel National.  Not quite as memorable.    Worth a try.  If the wait is too long for a table, grab a seat at the bar.

yAddvlqyzO_puuL1kZStHA.review_text: Uneven experience. Other comments on the high salt levels were on point - on a few dishes the salt was overwhelming.   Service started strong but timing began to slip as the meal went on. I'd consider going back for snacks and drinks, but they aren't delivering a full meal that is legitimate at the price point.

9U30DANobkrn3Zlu6T9p6Q.review_text: The 3 star average is insane. I new nothing about Tosca Cafe until my buddy started talking about some bar he used to post at regularly that was a San Francisco institution reopening w/ a restaurant serving April Bloomfield's grub. Posted up at the bar for dinner. Here's the rundown:  - Crispy Pig Tail - pass  - Off Menu Meatballs & Foccacia - double yes  - Radishes & Tuna Conserva - fantastic  - Market Salad - perfect  - Bucatini - a must  - Roasted Chicken for 2: I rarely order chicken when I'm out to eat, but the salmon and steak weren't doing it for me. Chicken was great and keeping the feet on was a nice touch.   Put this on your shortlist.

w_o3zjPJeBEuDnFRiCXTTQ.review_text: Excellent drinks.  Spectacular pasta.  Super cool vibe for the boy from Carolina. We sat at the bar, ordered the bucatini, broccoli and roasted potatoes.  Wasn't super hungry so we passed on the apps but saw a few come out and they all looked great.  Bar tenders are superior and deliver awesome cocktails with an appropriate amount of drama.

aqWXHhcR_CdmKmxggFOlEA.review_text: What a great spot! Dim lighting, but not too dark; dark wood, great vibe.   My friend and I showed up for dinner on a Thursday night around 8:30 p.m. - no reservations or anything, and the wait was over an hour. But food is served at the bar, and the bar is first come, first served; we found a couple of seats at the bar and were able to sit immediately.   We had prosecco, the speck and citrus salad, bucatini with guanciale and cauliflower gratin. Both the bucatini and the cauliflower gratin were both so great. The bucatini had some good bite and chewyness and not overly saucy. The cauliflower gratin was rich but somehow you feel okay eating it because it's cauliflower...  I don't find myself in North Beach very often, but if I did, this would be my go-to spot for drinks and bites.

zT7t1ECcvP88KCGSw_c42A.review_text: I went here for my fiancée birthday and we really enjoyed ourselves. I had the best pasta in my life, it was the rigatoni and it hands down best the bucatini. At the end we had wished we ordered more food!

B7xDljCT-OS_qaJtTtBdPA.review_text: I went here for our joint bdays with one of my besties. She said it got really great reviews and she was really excited about it.    The kitchen is interesting and it's a cute trend place. I'm a fan for sure, the bar got packed at around 9pm and there were attractive people on a Sat. Go with the paid parking down the street though unless you are feeling lucky. Can never find parking.

7OcRn5dPm2IlKUkEMtQvWw.review_text: Three of us stopped by around 5:30 Sat. evening to find a very nicely cleaned up Tosca.  We were dying for an Irish coffee, & had a hard time communicating this to the server, for some unknown reason.  I am a native San Franciscan,who grew up, so to speak, on Irish coffee at the Buena Vista, & assumed Tosca would know how to make them.  They finally arrived, but without the "float" of cream on the top, & luke warm, at that.  When the bill came, & we saw $40.00 for the three, we were shocked! The price of the food is also over what one would expect, & I'm not willing to eat there after the first impression that , frankly, left us cold!!  Skyking

eAavwM32i2h7sNNer--kGw.review_text: I saw this restaurant advertised on a website I subscribe to. I had high hopes, seeing as the description and pictures sounded and looked pretty good. My friend and I went in on a Tuesday night and I realize that I didn't have a reservation, but we had to wait for over an hour. On a Tuesday night!   Once we were seated, a member of the wait staff brought us water. He was very friendly... at first. When our waiter came to take our order, my friend and I had already had a chance to look at the menu and knew what we wanted. Our waiter read out the specials of the day, and when he had finished, we told him that we were ready to order. He then said to us, "So I just wasted my breath then." RUDE!!! When we told him what we wanted, he asked us if we wanted anything else to go with it, and we told him no but we would let him know if we changed our minds. He was very persistent and weird about telling us multiple times that if we wanted to order anything else, we had to let him know NOW because the food has to all come out together (what he should have said was are you sure you don't want anything else to go with your pasta, the portions are on the smaller side). I don't know what his  deal was. He then proceeded to walk over to where the host was standing, whisper something in his ear, and then they both turned to look at my friend and me in an obvious way.  Summary of our experience there: WEIRD. Not going back. Ever. Wait staff was weird, not to mention RUDE, food was expensive for such small portions, wait time was long, some of the prices for food was not the same on the menu as online menu.  Most likely will NOT be returning. What a disappointment.

opPL44lvjw_sBMxkGkM4-Q.review_text: In short, food - 2 stars, drink - 4 stars, dessert - 5 stars, service - 4 stars.  We went Tosca for dining, not for drink.  Unfortunately, all the dishes we ordered were too too much salty though the flavor was good.  However, Tosca is still in my list.  I will try again.

xTdIxiANFE6bQQaNhGJHBg.review_text: Love this place for the decor and the bartenders, not so much for that crowd, at least on my most recent visit.   Drinks are a little pricey but well made and delicious. I love that the new owners kept the original feel of the place.   Another one of my favorite stops in that neighborhood whenever I'm in town. Lots of other great places to check out in the immediate area.

kbtWpV_hc9U7LWdDhDqu7Q.review_text: Loved it before, and still love it.  An SF gem. I'm glad they didn't change the interior too much with the renovation.

VJ0fP8DlN4YeFkh0y1iciw.review_text: Spectacular Italian food.  Everything we had was exceptional.  Service Top notch.  Meat platter enough for 4.  Pasta delicious.  Small plates but enough to share.

2_ZGgdMoavEW3KxS-c2FxA.review_text: Cannot rate them on food yet, but just based on the bar scene.  All the new changes as now being a restaurant seem to be a successful venture. However, it's definitely lost its old SF charm.  Crowd is there because they want to be seen.  The drinks are good, but pricey but you're in SF so....   Other than wanting to be seen by "people" and paying too much for drinks, it's not worth it.  A good time can be easily had is a half a dozen places in North Beach simply by walking aimlessly.  I will go back to try the food, but Tosca will be only a memory now for what it used to be.  But, good for them that they are packing the house.

qIrgZ_iSRMyMOkJq5xt_8g.review_text: Note to Yelpers:  if your review is more than 3 paragraphs, I won't read it.  This is not Bon Appetit magazine. Get in and get out people.  Now, Tosca . . .   Food:  Why only 3 entrees on the actual menu, with 5 specials announced by the waiter?  Just print a daily menu with the specials included.  Don't you have a printer?  The food overall was very good.  Caesar, pasta and meatballs all above average.  Cocktails were inventive and top notch.  Service:  I would refer to it as hipster indifference.  Bearded waiters just didn't seem that interested.  Never asked how we were.  Took forever for focaccia bread.  Brings dessert, but not coffee.  Coffee (excellent) comes after dessert is gone.  3 different waiters served us, when all we needed was one good one.  Price:  Not cheap and the portions are pretty small.  Sadly I have gotten used to paying $ 100.00 for me and my girlfiend to have a fancy snack.    Not sure I would go back, considering the lame service.

RhUQ1Vz3-bDMLbIGlcyzfA.review_text: Tosca Café redux: better than the original.  From all the coverage in the traditional media and the blogosphere, you might have confused the re-opening of Tosca Café with the Second Coming.  No, it's just a re-take on an iconic North Beach restaurant / bar.    While there are now great food offerings at Tosca Café, the star, as before, is the bar.   Isaac Shumway has created a cocktail program based on the classics:  from the Casino Bar negroni ($12, Beefeater gin, Campari, Antica Formula, and orange peel) to the aptly named suffering bastard ($12, almanac, St. George Terroir gin, pressed ginger, lime, bitters, and soda), they are all good--maybe too good.  There is a fine selection of wines by the glass and by the bottle, and with Drakes IPA ($8), Borgo oyster stout ($11), as well as other offerings, beer aficionados will not be disappointed.  Chef April Bloomfield's food is almost as good as the drinks.  The bucatini ($17) with tomato, chili pepper, and guanciale was delicious. While it may not give Zuni Café a run for its money, the roast chicken for two ($42) is succulent and juicy. However, despite the accompaniments of mushrooms, mascarpone, and parmesan, the grilled polenta ($17) was a little disappointing.   While well-meaning, service was a little confused: servers, bus personnel, hosts, and bar staff need to learn the ins-and-outs of their positions.  Pacing of courses was a little off, but the timing errors were not egregious enough to destroy the experience.  Buzzing again with life, the all new Tosca does justice to, and improves upon, memories of days past..

LbXPxx2HwO9yz7RkOQP3QA.review_text: I want to like it. I mean Beyonce ate here. But alas, I felt like it was disappointing.  First of all, our server had no menu knowledge. When asking for recommendations, he could not give anymore information than that which was already printed on the menu. This is the kind of place where the cocktails are way better than the food. So cocktails maybe should get 4-5 stars.  Foodwise, we got.... Pig tails - gross. So greasy. We didn't even finish these. It was honestly like fried bones. pickled veggies - came in a very small teacup, meh. 3 pastas: Bucatini, Rigatoni, Linguini. All of which, were lacking in real depth of flavor. They were all oily and oversalted.  bottom line: come for drinks only. the food is kind of expensive and it is subpar italian cuisine.

QOMoA_G5PBrUA_WXu1ZdIg.review_text: What a great job on new tosca! Been here twice since renovation and enjoyed the drinks and food. Food is  on a greezier/cheesier side which is good for drinking:) takes forever to get your order too. They are busy!! Will come again yes!

qHmLQQZF1GKrU6HFZqZqGA.review_text: Dined here in the private room on Christmas Eve and our group of 9 had a pre-fixe 4-course menu.   To start- Crispy Pig Tails- really delicious and oh so fatty! "Point Reyes Blue" Salad- there was a lottt of blue cheese! House-baked foccacia- we asked for refills like 3 times. Fresh and addicting.  2nd course- Bucatini. Wow, the pasta was amazing! The perfect bite and just enough sauce. Highly recommend getting this dish.  3rd course- Whole Roasted Chicken. (Broccoli and Crispy Potatoes as sides) The chicken was so moist! Their marsala sauce was perfect atop the chicken and sides. The crispy potatoes were fried in pork fat- reminded me of my favorite potatoes at Plow except more fatty and fried!  4th course- Tiramisu with orange zest. A perfect end to the meal! There was definitely a lot of rum which we all loved.  As in other reviews of the restaurant, the service was spotty but not entirely horrible. It was tolerable but there were some long pauses in between courses and getting refills of anything.  Overall, a solid 4 stars and definitely want to try their famous "Cappacuino" next time.

yKF3gzA8MxJO54RA-S2Uxg.review_text: Used to be a nice hang-out and part of a wonderful varied group of area pubs - Mr Bings, Specs, Vensuvios, Tosca...  Cross Tosca off the list, it thinks its hip but has become very uncool - barmen all bearded; crowded with the "IN CROWD"; long waits for drinks (about 20 minutes for the CAP).  The heart and soul of the place has been ripped out, same basic look but no life.  We were sad to see it this way, finished our drinks and moved on.  Not worth a return visit for anyone that used to go, and hardly worth the visit for visitors to the City.

xPd-lodXhvc6SHuUkfX3mQ.review_text: I have to commend the group that did the renovations of Tosca. It still has the classy vintage feel, warm and inviting. It was nice to see the gigantic vintage steamer machine sitting at the end of the bar first thing upon entering. I remembered the old warm cocoa and brandy drinks we had one late afternoon when I came in with out of town friends to escape the cold, foggy, wet mist about two years ago. The bartender back then was an older gentleman, who had lined up about 12 of those cute vintage glasses, which they still use, (Yay) and was filling them with some kind of powder. I remember thinking it looked like nestle quick mix. Back then it felt charming.   Last night, the first time going back there since they reopened, I missed the old gentleman immediately. He doesn't work there any more. The new staff was friendly enough, I love the crisp white jackets they wear, but I found it annoying that the gal bartender was texting in front of me. I must be old fashioned. She recommended I give the house cappuccino a try, and it was so much better than the nestle quick one I remembered. Better than charming. Truly a little piece of heaven and worth the $12.   We did not order any food so I can not comment on that. The 3 star review is because the modern music, which I love in other locations, felt discombobulated in a classy vintage environment. It was later in the evening though and there was a young crowd...I get it. I'm young too, but I wanted the throwback-nod-to-a-more-gentile time, experience. The two person ladies room with the door that locks really sucks. A woman went in and locked the door with just herself in there. Maybe she was sick? Maybe I should say thanks for not letting me hear you do something nasty? Maybe they should take the lock off the door?   I will say the hand soap in there smelled wonderful. I kept smelling my hands all night. I need to eat food before I pass judgment and get too negative. Plan to go back earlier so we can really appreciate the full experience and hope they play some old big band tunes or something like that.

08mOpJRCpZe3D8UHszP4FA.review_text: Checked out the newly reopened Tosca Cafe.  We got there around 6pm on a Sat and the place was super busy, was told an hour wait.  Gave them a cell number to call us when a table was ready.  Got the call to return back for our table almost 1hr later.  They have a music jukebox, I couldn't get it to play, but I think it does work.  FREE still or sparkling tap water.  That's nice.  We got sparkling.    Tried out:  Oxtail terrine $8 - tiny portion of some cubed oxtail meat and other stuff, served cold.  Pretty gross, Skip it.  Cesar salad $12 - tiny portion of salad, I think barely enough for 1 person, 2 people not enough for both.  I did like it, but not for $12!  Rigatoni pasta $16 - tiny ass portion again, too al-dente for us, we didn't like it much.  Bucatini $17 - small portion of the pasta, we liked the taste though.  Overall, overpriced & tiny portions & super LOUD in there, Won't be back.

R_IvZ-PrpXd3uSSnxANFYg.review_text: Wow....Let me begin by saying,"After reading several Yelp reviews and the initial vibe I was getting when first entering the restaurant, I was skeptical." (When we get caught in traffic driving into the city for 90 min., it's frustrating to arrive just after the restaurant has opened and wonder if we'll get a table - just a personal challenge of mine.) Fortunately, I had the chance to sit at the bar for a bit and unwind before my husband met me. A friendly bartender greeted me and shared the cocktail and wine list...even offered a taste of Italian wine. After he offered to mix me up something special, I requested a margarita. (I know, not very adventurous.) From the alcohol offerings on the menu, I assumed they would have some tasty tequila. Margarita was delicious. Just the right mix of tart and sweetness. The man sitting next to me noted Tosca's bar menu included a very rare Bourbon - $50/glass. Upon checking in with the host, the restaurant has a policy that you cannot be seated until your entire party arrives. Unless there's valet, parking is never easy in SF. As I watched parties arriving, I assumed there was no way we would have an opportunity to be seated in the restaurant without a long wait. Fortunately, my husband really wanted to try this restaurant, so once he joined me, we relaxed at the bar, enjoying drinks and conversation. You often meet friendly and fun people sitting at the bar. We chatted and shared experiences about other nearby restaurants. I began to relax and decided not to stress over the wait. We could always eat at the bar. We ended up being seated in the back of the restaurant. My husband is all about ambiance and atmosphere. He would have preferred to sit in the front and more active area of the restaurant, which gives one a look at the open kitchen, however, it was nice to hear our conversation and check out all the pictures of famous people who we gather frequented Tosca Cafe in the past. Given what we've read in the foodie and SF Magazines, Tosca Cafe has been around forever and the likes of Sean Penn, Mickey Rourke and others, out of sight from the front of the restaurant, played pool and talked late into the night. As we ordered, chatted with Jordan, our server, you could imagine the nostalgia of years past. Our selections included warm rolls, meatballs, grilled polenta, asparagus and clams. The rolls, doused with olive oil, garlic and parmesan cheese came out with the meatballs. OK, so I'm Italian and make meatballs, which I've been told are pretty tasty. I've never had meatballs that were as tender and perfectly seasoned. Amazing flavors. I could have stopped after that course. The polenta was served with delicious mushrooms and the asparagus was grilled and topped with parmesan cheese and almonds - also perfectly seasoned. Finally, I believe it was Manilla clams in a scrumptious tomato, garlic and onion mix that completed our delicious tastings. Desserts looked inviting, however, we were stuffed. It was probably that extra order of garlic rolls. The only comment (and it's not negative) that I offer for people interested in eating at Tosca Cafe, arrive early and together, if you're hoping to get seated in the first round, otherwise prepare for a wait. Tosca does not take reservations. Our very competent and friendly server did say that the rear area of the restaurant can be reserved for larger parties, etc. Tks Jordan for a delightful first experience at Tosca Cafe. We'll return and bring friends.

1A-geB-PQr1uveSFOS7Feg.review_text: Expect a long wait.  We were told the wait would be up to 3 hours on the Saturday evening we stopped in.  Rather than wait for a table, we grabbed a seat at the bar.  I think if we go back, we'd do the same; in our opinion, the ambiance in the bar section is actually more inviting and cozy than the dining area.   We ordered an appetizer - however, we dined here months ago, so I frankly can't remember what it was.  The real stand out of our meal was the roasted chicken (takes over an hour once you put in your order, so plan ahead) and the duck fat fried potatoes.  Those potatoes - oh my gosh, so tasty.  So crispy on the outside, served pipping hot - and the flavor...outstanding.  I want to go back if not only for those fried duck fat potatoes!  Also - excellent drinks. The service was also great.

_0UXptnf1DtCqqYByMBS0Q.review_text: Went here on our first night out in SF and were welcomed by knowledgeable, friendly and super fun bartenders w a trendy and fun ambiance.  They made us feel right at home, suggesting drinks and giving us taste tests of their incredibly unique beverages! I loved everything about this place. Our main bartender had just moved there from Australia and could not have been a more interesting and cool person to chat with while he whipped up some amazing elaborate drinks. Customer service people. ITS SO SIMPLE! Sadly a lot of places miss that concept.   We wanted to go back again before we left but never made it in there but I would recommend this cozy spot to anyone venturing out in the city!!!

OGUBC7uz8yqySaCZDK8tsg.review_text: The bar and cocktails are great but somehow when you cross that threshold to the restraunt the vibe changes.  Snippy host, decent service but terribly over priced, mediaocre food .  The price point is similar to Perbacco or other top Italian establishments but not even close in quality.  I'm very disappointed in M Bauer's review as he is clearly cow toeing to the NYC food mob.  Try the food, judge for yourself.

vurvJX_rVIvGSdAgeGtqKA.review_text: Tosca cafe, newly renovated by chef April Bloomfield has brought contemporary Italian dishes to North Beach! We started off with the deviled egg. Perfectly balanced, good flavor, not going to change your world. Meatballs and foccaccia are not on the menu, but you can order them anyway. The meatball is tender and juicy, but the sauce is the star of the show. Foccacia is humongous, nicely salted and seasoned with rosemary. The buccatini is small, but incredibly rich. The guanciale is crispy and adds a pleasant crunch. Try the linguine and clams, nice and light, again on the small side portion wise, but it's rich. Come for the cocktails, the "cappuccino" has no coffee in it. Try the "dirty" if you're looking for a coffee buzz. The decor is too dark to snap instagram photos so don't bother. This place is pricey and will not blow your mind. It is however, a solid place to go for apps and cocktails.

d8A4EU8sJlKsRAFYYyCO4A.review_text: This has become one of my favorite places in SF.  I love the old school vibe and the food is awesome.  The best is the minestrone soup, quite possibly the best soup I've ever had.  I order it as my entree with some vegetable sides and the super yummy focaccia bread.  If they have meatballs as a special - those are a must have.  They actually take reservations and they're on Open Table..  It's a small restaurant though and there aren't many tables than can seat more than 4 people.  It's easiest to get a table for 2.

hXC3vuCPWUCCtfa_Fsug2Q.review_text: So I promised the staff that I would write a review because they treated me so well. It's also better late than never because I went some weeks back and maybe they forgot my promise.  Anyways, they did me well and I really appreciated their services. It was almost as if we were old friends (cheesy,  true though).   They called me by name and checked up on me for drinks, for food and getting a table. The atmosphere was amazing and the place was packed but they diligently brought us our drinks and were sympathetic about the table wait.  I didn't mind at all because I was getting down on their delicious drinks.  I got the good booth table with tasty entrees and played some good tunes on the free jukebox.  All in all, thanks to the staff and hopefully you remember that I remembered.  Spence

9o_ePu9wfQZFpnE8Nss27Q.review_text: Echoing the underwhelmed sentiment.  Following the Bon Appétit write-up and rave reviews from friends I was prepared to have my world rocked, but to no avail. Over-seasoned, small portions, and checked-out service.  I was with a party of four that started off sharing several small plates to begin, as well as some house cappuccinos all around. Cappuccinos were alright, nothing that I would write home about. We shared meatballs, focaccia, fried artichoke, and the crispy potatoes. Focaccia and meatballs were great, but I will definitely say any sharing of the small plates (antipasti) is best done between two people. You'd need at least two orders of everything we had to constitute a decent serving size per person, even just for an appetizer.  As for the artichoke, I could not taste the mint or oregano for the life of me. The red wine vinegar overpowered any other flavor that could have possibly come through. Crispy potatoes were so crispy they were difficult to bite into by the time they got to our table, and way too salty.  All around we had a decent meal, but if you're going to be touted as one of the best new restaurants in America by such a respected food publication, you had better be ready to deliver on the title.

mrXim_3tiYt3FuIf3lSRYA.review_text: Just got back from the bar. Got there at 5:10 and sat right down. When we left at 5:40 place was jammed.  The room is great. Perfect 40's vibe. Busy but not loud.  Ordered a Corpse Reviver. Bartender said "1 or 2?"  Yes there are two versions and we wanted the "2". Drink was perfectly chilled and right on. She knows her booze and it was fun to watch her work.

QLd5JVa5bt2PamRe5onH2A.review_text: The moment I feeling now love this place now I walked in. it is the fact.... Is so classy and old school make you happy. if you forget about these things when you visit all these hip new restaurants in SF.   Otherwise .... The food, drink, staff quality and enter the service is great and responsible. The all drink have picked and the enter drink was so tasty.  Gone ...... and earned.

Kr9TSi4vz6SHDuPfORtjzw.review_text: The food was horrible and the service mediocre at best. The hostess was the only good thing at this restaurant. Inedible fritto misto, unless you like eating crustacean shells. We would never return. Nor should you.

GnkhVQoyUgFtnpBE_gnk3g.review_text: I'm really surprised by the negative reviews! I recently moved to the Bay Area from NY, and Tosca is one of the few restaurants in SF that I happily return to again and again. Sure, don't go on a Friday/ Saturday night as it'll be overcrowded and too noisy. But it's like going to bars-- you have to go on the off nights for the best experience, service included.  The food has been consistently delicious every time I've been. Their antipasti are perfect to nibble on with your cocktails, and be sure not to leave without their fresh pasta (I recommend the bucatini and linguini). Vegetable sides are fresh and well seasoned. Stay a little longer, and order a Suffering Bastard and Trouble in Paradise!

J26rLFEmURqUVADQYYxqBQ.review_text: This is a fun bathroom mainly because of the marilyns everywhere. Interesting that there is a lock for a 4+ person bathroom. One of those superpower air dryers. No towel option.

3G9Jkn7hKc8fmbdK8_lC8g.review_text: after having changed hands Tosca Cafe cannot be held to their old standards. sure the dishes are more expensive but their quality has increased as well. April Bloomfield's people have done a great job keeping the menu simple and executing them well. i've read plenty of reviews that complain about the salt content but during my dining experience there the only thing that was overly salted was the fat fried potatoes. everything else from the succulent, juicy, full of flavor meatballs to the perfectly al dente bucatini and vegetables were well seasoned. i thoroughly enjoyed dinner at Tosca. the server was great and well informed about their wines and the hostess made sure to coordinate with the server when i handed them my credit card earlier in the evening so that i could force payment before my boyfriend's parents got to the bill. fantastic! no wonder Bon Appetit named it one of US's top 10 restaurants of 2014!

qe9OwFZHNI8fS73li2nY-g.review_text: One of the best dining experiences of my life. I went with just my mother, and we definitely got more food than was necessary. But it was so hard to choose what to get because it's an amazing menu. To start we got giardiniera, meatballs, focaccia. For the larger plates we had the skirt steak, lumaconi, and roasted beets. For dessert we shared the dark chocolate sorbetto and a coffee gelato (we might've mixed them like children). For drinks I got a moscow mule and a glass of Vallana Spanna. Every time I began to taste something I would freak out, but I seriously had to try and not make a scene in front of the waitstaff. It's been two weeks since this meal, and I am still thinking about the brussels sprouts in the giadiniera and how they have no bitterness at all and only taste like their pickling juice, which was so subtle and sweet and spicy. Those brussels sprouts are haunting me. The focaccia is by far the best I've ever had. It's lavishly covered in really strong olive oil, it crackles when you bite into it, but it's so warm and doughy. It's also extremely thick for focaccia, and like the brussels sprouts, I can't figure out how they do it. The lumanconi was delicious, probably my favorite, and our waiter said it was the staff's favorite as well. They use the prosciutto ends! PROSCIUTTO ENDS! It's really lemony and the breadcrumbs make it crunch. The steak was cooked perfectly, and came with mushrooms that were just as good as the steak. I swear. They were ridiculously flavorful and meaty and just perfect. It's hard for me to think of words right now because I am recalling all of the great flavors and textures of the food, and I'm becoming lightheaded.   NOT ONLY WAS IT PRETTY MUCH THE BEST FOOD I'VE EVER EATEN... The service was by far the best. My water glass was never even halfway empty, or was it always more than halfway full? Whatever. My glass was always full! I went to the restroom and they refolded my napkin for me. And yes it was formal and professional, but the service didn't lack personality or generosity. They saw how much we were enjoying the food (because we were pretty much screaming), and brought us complimentary potatoes! We had a really nice conversation with our waiter too. The waiters were so nice and somewhat restored my faith in humanity? Yes, maybe. It's also in one of the best parts of the city, and is such a beautiful space. It's pretty much the perfect restaurant and I don't need to go to another restaurant ever again. Thank you, April Bloomfield.

W2jwEOlGSXUkf86d05Ijgw.review_text: So disappointing. The food was terrible and expensive. For the price, you could eat at Zuni or Boulevard. Instead, you have Tosca which charges $$$$$ for food I would find sub-par at a diner. What a joke.  The service was bizarre.  It took several minutes to get acknowledged by a buss boy with water, then we had an even longer wait to put in a drink order.  Then I got to watch our server walk around the room gossiping with staff while holding my wine glass.  After finally ordering, we watched the chef shoving food into her mouth on the line, but unfortunately not cooking our food. 45 minutes later, our crab salad and sausage plate arrived.  We were never asked if we wanted another drink.  TL;DR: save your money for a legit restaurant. This place is a joke.

uf3nRzvQiLXqP8KTCpBkaw.review_text: Came here for dinner on a Thursday night with the boyfriend. We shared the Crispy Pig Tails ($9), Rigatoni ($16), Linguini ($17), Hanger Steak ($25), and Crispy Potatoes ($7). We also had a Polo Cup and a Whiskey Smash based on the waitress's recommendation, which were both delicious and strong!  I would say that the Crispy Pig Tails and the Rigatoni were definitely the standouts of the meal, while the Linguini, Hanger Steak, and Crispy Potatoes left much to be desired. The rigatoni sauce was PERFECT.  The linguini was extremely oily, and didn't have much of a flavor to it save for the clams. The Hanger Steak was cooked extremely well, however also lacking flavor. Unfortunately, the Crispy Potatoes were way too salty for our palettes, and we had to wash it down with a lot of water.  I wouldn't strongly recommend this place to my friends, but would not mind returning for some drinks.

gisZy0HKXvX4YMspboRmZQ.review_text: How is it that they only have 3 stars?!  Look, Bartlett Hall has 12$ well drinks. This place is chock full of charm, history, and masters of craft in both food and drink. Did they mention that they have the best negroni in San Francisco? No? Did i mention the house cappuccino is ridiculous?   Look, it's not the cheapest place on the planet, admittedly. but trust me, this place is worth every penny.

vf1DBLUOG4qHYxs7qCAXUA.review_text: Great slice of SF history. Although you know it has been fully updated it looks the same as it did at the party after La Boheme in 1975 (or 76?, the 70's are a bit of a blur). Jeannette should be very honored.   Drinks were great as was the bucatini.   Hearty Bravo to our server Tyler who was great and recommended the house cappuccino which was the perfect way to end the evening (BTW, it has no coffee).

KDewJBJknfWvQyHHFNbfdg.review_text: Expectations is a game people play. No one should expect Tosca to remain the same after such a shift from the old guard to April Bloomfield's team now owning it. And every type of approach to a bar like this is commendable, even more commendable considering that Bloomfield's team saved this place from the unsavory landlord who owns North Beach's notorious strip clubs as he raised the rent with nefarious plans for the space. Take it as a sign of the times for San Francisco, certainly, however the negativity coming straight from the gullet here in these first few fistful of reviews for the new Tosca are pretty unwarranted.   I frequented the old Tosca about one sixtieth as much as Sean Penn use to back in his prime. I use to sit in the back booth and order proper martinis either alone or with a friend, and the most astonishing aspect of the nights was the table service. Rarely do you get such a perfect San Francisco martini at your seat. Guess what... that hasn't changed. Not a bit. They spruced up the place and kept the same red lamp tone of the space. Yes, of course, after the litany of Eater emails in desk jockey inboxes, of course the front of the house is packed every single night as the allure of being a part of the old guard of San Francisco is strong for the new era of this city's polished aristocracy, however effete. I have no qualms at all with the company of parrots paying seven shekels a pint to maintain the possibility that I can linger in one of these booths all night long.   The menu has upped its game to near Spotted Pig levels. Thank you Ms. Bloomfield. The drinks just the same. The House Cappucino remains.   Maybe Yelpers haven't recognized the change as a good thing. If anything, Tosca's increased prices are properly supporting a growing reliance on the service industry. Consider the sky-rocketing cost of living in this city, and Tosca is on par, and no I'm not someone who can afford to be at this place more often than most. In fact, I'm not someone who could afford being at any bar, including the old priced Tosca, more than most. I'm just realistic about how much booze should cost. Yes, there's an immediate urge to defend nostalgia and the abandonment of a lost time. Most of us were never a part of that era. While people complain about the exorbitant costs of a lemon drop, the old guys romanticized of the old days of this city are likely thinking about how charming this city use to be -- when people cared enough to complain about having to step over their brethren on the streets who can barely afford to eat. I really question whether or not their allegiance to the old guard of Tosca is as vehement as they say, or are they riding the wave of disdain of a changing San Francisco?  Money was the motivation to ruin this place into the ground. Money saved it. They could've gutted it and stuffed it with $40 salami. They could be serving $15 martinis like we see in D.C. and Manhattan. Instead, they have integrity. I'll fork over earned dollars to make sure Tosca stays in the hands of those whose allegiance is to Tosca. My expectations for our city remains the same: look hard enough and you find integrity resting in a red booth over a proper martini.

Gwb9rLRFBhIFnINf0IXyew.review_text: Great addition to North Beach scene. Earlier bad reviews appear to be based on the first week the "new" Tosca Cafe reopened and was still working out the kinks. We went with a party of five early (about 6 PM) on a Saturday evening. Lucky to be seated right away in a booth. (When we left about 8:30 PM I overheard the hostess tell someone the wait was 90 minutes.) Our service was great --- very professional --- especially the wine director. Drinks okay. Food was fine. Pricey, but no more than any other comparable tourist neighborhood restaurant in the City. Noise level average --- all five of us could carry on a conversation. We'll go back.

h1WweAH6dmG5Gx9gUeA3mw.review_text: Great place! You just need to get there early and get a seat at the bar. Great cocktails!

6MwGjz0MwwjstQT8lp03Tg.review_text: I am torn about this review as I wanted to like Tosca more than I did. Starting from the beginning, we were seated promptly. The space itself feels warm like it has history, but not old. However the banquette where we were seated was too small for four. The restaurant also was very warm and we all stuck to the vinyl.   Service was mixed, starting well but then sliding into neglect. Our server was friendly but then forgot to refill wine and the length between courses got longer and longer. One person's steak took extra time so they comped a dessert.   The food itself was pretty good but very salty. The focaccia bread to start was delicious. I got the radish salad and bucatini which were both good. Others liked their dishes but too salty was a common refrain. The desserts were very one note and surprisingly ordinary. The cannoli lacked any sweetness. The last thing is the wine list which struck me as very expensive.   Tosca has gotten a lot of good press but I can't really compare it to favorites like Rich Table and State Bird.

DjFsfJWkzRuDszuJWTsSXQ.review_text: This is a three-star place.  I really wanted it be better, but it's not.    We booked a prime time table on a Saturday; the place was busy but not bustling.  Perhaps almost a year in, the novelty has worn off.  Lots to like about this place.  It's flat out gorgeous.  Beautifully re-done, keeping all the elegance and character of the space.  Warm lighting and tables spaced out far enough for conversation.  The booths look especially charming (we had a two-top).  I will say the vibe is a little casual for the pricing, so keep that in mind.  Food is well-done but nothing particularly memorable.  We started with oxtail and chicken liver; both nice.  The minestrone was good, but the excessive salt took away from the freshness of the ingredients.   Both pastas were good, but not mind blowing.  I thought the wine list was aggressively priced.   It's a thoughtful and ambitious place, but Tosca didn't quite work for me.   All-in-all, it makes for a great date night, but not really worth the trip across the city. And, relatively to what I'd call Tosca's competition (Contagna, Locanda, Beretta) it falls short.  p.s. No valet in North Beach for a upscale restaurant!?  Um, really?

pme7GsuU86rKc78DMoyBIQ.review_text: Pleasant surprise to see Tosca Cafe back, they still have super yummy house cappuccino going on w/ an artisan SF based chocolate maker,Dandelion. Also It's extremely convenient that they serve food and keep the kitchen open till 1 am which is quiet hard to get in North Beach and many other parts of the city. I liked the fact that they kept the original decoration but polished is nicely so it didn't lose it's soul.

ao3OM2qTqwA5qpIF4UHaJg.review_text: Avoid this place. I tried this with a couple friends. The service has been consistently troubling. Also, even with the revamp, the food is just * okay*. For instance, the focaccia was dryer than would be desired, the meatballs were definitely overpriced and the pasta was waaaay oversauced and soggy/wet.  To add to this, we were asked to leave after an hour and fifteen minutes by the manager because they wanted to use the table in the middle of SantaCon. Classy.

CZ36wJqV-Xit758UaOr81A.review_text: I don't understand the 3-star overall rating for Tosca Cafe. Other Yelpers ripped their food for no good reason. However, I think I discovered why after doing some research. Tosca Cafe was taken over by Michelin Star chef April Bloomfield sometime last year. If you're not familiar with Bloomfield, she's a British chef famous for her New York restaurants, The Spotted Pig and The Breslin (both hold a Michelin Star) and for her beatdown of Michael Symon on Iron Chef in 2008 where she still holds the highest score of any challenger (56). I believe a lot of the "hate" Tosca is receiving has something to do with her being a New York chef. It's not a secret that SF and NY have an ongoing culinary rivalry. I believe that very element has forced hardcore SF locals to downplay Tosca Cafe. I don't fault anyone for showing pride for their city. In fact, I welcome and encourage it. But it shouldn't prevent people from giving credit when it's absolutely deserved.   Dined here this past Saturday night with 10 other people. We ordered several of each item to share. Before I dive into the dishes, I have to give everyone a heads up - Tosca's portions are very small. Their menu is constructed to encourage you to order four courses (Antipasti, 1st, 2nd and 3rd course with the possibility of sides and desert).   ***ANTIPASTI*** MEATBALLS (Three pre order) ~ $11 ~ 5 stars CRISPY PIG TAILS ~ $9 ~ 5stars FOCCACIA BREAD (Enough for 4 people) ~ 4.5 stars MOSCARDINI (Octopus) ~ $9 ~ 4 stars  ***PASTAS*** BUCATINI ~ $17 ~ 5 stars GEMELLI ~ $16 ~ 5 stars LINGUINI ~ $15 ~ 4 stars RIGATONI ~ $14 ~ 3.5 stars GRILLED POLENTA ~ $17 ~ 3 stars  ***MAIN*** WHOLE ROASTED CHICKEN (1-hour prep time) ~ $42 ~ 3.5 stars  The Meatballs (off-menu item) are to die for. Flavor is on-point and the texture is what you expect from a Michelin Star chef - moist, tender. The Crispy Pig Tails might sound disgusting but it's anything but that. Deep friend to perfection. Imagine combining the best pork rinds you've ever had with little morsels or perfectly cooked, fall-off-the-bone meat. Absolutely amazing. The Foccacia had excellent flavor. A very aromatic bread that went very well with the Meatballs and the sauce it sat in. Moscardini? Never heard of it? It's octopus cooked to an amazing tender texture. Dressed with a simple vinaigrette and you get a winner.   We sampled all their pasta offerings. Don't waste your time on anything else but their Bucatini and Gemelli. The Bucatini had amazing flavor. Imagine macaroni pasta stretched to the length of spaghetti. That's what bucatini is. The sauce had very deep and complex flavors. You can taste all the quality ingredients and the Gruanciale (essentially bacon) really adds another layer of taste and texture. The Gemelli was on-point. It's a type of pasta I never heard of. It essentially looks like two strands of pasta twisted together, each piece about 3/4 of an inch long. The pecorino comes through beautifully and you get a nice subtle black pepper finish.   The roasted chicken was good but not great. However, the sauce was creamy and a tad citrusy. It's perfect with the foccacia.   They have a healthy list of premium cocktails. I tried the Casino Bar Negroni, Suffering Bastard and House "Cappuccino". All were very good and well made. The Cappuccino is the perfect way to cap off an awesome dinner. We also brought six bottles of wine. Each one had a standard $25 corkage fee.   The biggest knock I have on Tosca is their service. The staff makes you feel like you're below them. Everything from how they say things to their facial expressions are big turnoffs. It's not the most welcoming place. They did show flashes of courtesy and quality service once in awhile but it's definitely something they need to improve on. Plus, it's nothing several drinks can't take care of. This is one place I'd be happy to return to even though the service was bad. The food was THAT good.   We didn't have reservations. However, our party of 11 only had to wait 45 minutes after showing up around 6:15pm on Saturday. Don't show up any later if you have a bigger party because the place got packed by 7pm.

dugBVGBnagCMLfgES6-Niw.review_text: The service is good, ambience exceptional, the drinks above average (except for the Apple Toddy, which I couldn't finish to the bitter end), then why just a two star review, you may ask.   The food. Did we pick a bad day, I doubt it.   My friend and I ordered Linguini (meh), meatballs (competent) and grilled lamb chops which we had to send back given how badly cooked it was. Not much meat and too much fat riding on the bones; this was one experience I wish I didn't have, because I've had such a romanticized notion of this place.   That said if you insist on going, ask to be seated in the back-room filled with movie posters. Imagine Sean Penn's Facebook profile and his likes come to life. Very laid back, very cool retro movie vibe. Now that's definitely worth two stars just by itself.

0DsxbQxw1cPRvbMkJmGwVA.review_text: Went  on a thursday night. Food was tasty (Loved the chicken liver Spiedini & Lamb chop). . Bar very noisy.

WP3p6rPGM6-MmyRNL_tglg.review_text: The service completely ruins what otherwise would be a delightful restaurant. The first time we visited, the service was lacking but the food was wonderful. So we went back but this time the food could not make up for the atrocious service.  We ordered a full chicken when we checked in for our reservation knowing the chicken takes one hour to prepare. After sharing a few small plates, we waited and waited and waited for the chicken. One hour and forty five minutes after we had ordered the chicken, it finally arrived.  I get that the kitchen can be backed up. But expecting guests to wait extra 45 mins for the main dish without a warning ( when ordering) is inexcusable. Also inexcusable was the waiter pushing us to order additional appetizers and entrees while we waited. The gracious thing would have been to apologize and send out a couple of apps on the house instead of telling the table "I'm just the messenger" and pointing out pasta dishes we could order while we wait.
